WRITING.TEXT: Student loans are their own special form of hell. They're outrageously expensive, agreed to when you're hardly an adult, and can loop so many people into it. You have every right to be scared and upset about them because it is such bullshit. You may be able to request a deferment on your loans. [Here's a bunch of information about it](https://studentaid.ed.gov/sa/repay-loans/deferment-forbearance).

Oh, God. That is a special form of hell. I'm trans, too, and it's nerve\-wracking enough just existing in society. I can't imagine being in a space that is so hostile towards us. You could probably try something like [7 Cups](https://www.7cups.com/). It's an online\-based therapy service. You can talk one on one with a listener for free and they do have professionals available. You can also get more traditional sessions for a certain amount of money per month (It's cheaper than what a therapist charges per hour in the US) I haven't used it extensively, but I've heard some good things about it. Another option is to try the [Trans Lifeline](https://www.translifeline.org/). It's based out of the United States, but I think you could get around any kind of region blocking by using something like a Google Voice number. It isn't fair or right that you're going through this. I know that some people will try to say "Well, why don't you just move?" and for a lot of people that's just not feasible.

Dear Lord do I feel that! You are so not alone in that regard. Last year I avoided Facebook for like two months after my birthday because I couldn't stand all of the well\-wishing. These people come out of the woodwork for shit like that but then don't talk to me for the other 364 days of the year. If you don't mind me being a bit of a weeb for second, there's a really good song about this topic. It's ["Unhappy Birthday" by Kairiki Bear](https://youtu.be/qfVnQSt1--U). The same producer has a good variety of songs about different things like isolation, suicide, fear of people, and others.

I don't have *extreme* chronic pain (typically it's mild to moderate), but I did have to rely on a cane for things last year and it really fucking sucks. It was embarrassing to have to walk with it since I'm still a young adult and the pitying looks from other people made me want to smash some faces in. Chronic health conditions, whether physical or mental, are terrible. Especially when you're young because no one seems to believe you. Have you ever looked into or have been asked about Complex PTSD (aka C\-PTSD)? [Here's some information on it from Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complex_post-traumatic_stress_disorder). It's basically PTSD that has been stretched out over a long period of time and is often found with people who've been abused as a kid. It shares some signs and symptoms with PTSD, but some of the special symptoms are things like impaired memory and poor emotional regulation. It isn't included in the DSM, even though it's been proposed for the last two editions. I'm glad that you do have a partner who accepts you for who you are. It's important to have a net of people who will be there for you. I fear that the trans issues are only getting started in the US. It's terrifying that we have people in power who are such bigots. I mean, gay marriage was only won a few years ago. It still feels like we can have everything ripped from us again.

*You are not a bad person for being sick.* People try to imply that all the time and it's bullshit. I'm in the same boat with the ACA. It's terrifying to me that I can again be denied coverage because of what conditions I have or have had in the past. And if it's not a total refusal of coverage, they make your monthly payments and deductibles absurdly high. No one should be denied healthcare on the basis of whether or not they can afford it. It makes me extremely uneasy that the Congress could force a bill through that would kill the preexisting conditions clause. I was white knuckling it last year when it came down to Senator McCain and thank the stars he was against it. Most people don't understand that they're only one illness or accident away from losing everything.

I'm sorry to report that Medicaid is also a bust. I'm looking for places to get treatment and most of them are a good 90\+ miles away from me. That's not to mention the fact that it's a pain in the ass just to find out if providers will cover you. Can we have universal healthcare? Please?

Most artists don't hit their stride while they are still in their early 20s. Although, trying to create something and hitting a brick wall again and again is probably one of the worst experiences that artists do go through. It's even worse when you're surrounded by successful creatives and you begin to compare yourself to them. Have you ever heard of "[The Gap](https://youtu.be/3ResTHKVxf4)"? It's a pretty popular speech segment. Basically, it's the distance between what your work is and what you want it to be. You're supercritical about your own work because you can see what could be and just don't have the means to express it quite yet. You have really good tastes, but your skill level just isn't quite there. It's something that every creative professional (and amateurs!) go through. It can take years to get through it. Do you have any sort of peer group that is willing to give you constructive feedback about your works? The chances are very good that you don't suck as much as you think that you do. We can get bogged down by the flaws in your work that you can't see where your work shines. I've been taking photography seriously as a career choice for 12 years. It took me 6 years to get good enough for formal education and another 4 to finally start creating work that I like. I spent a good chunk of time detesting my work and questioning what I was doing. Each time I found that when I didn't have a camera on me, I wished I had a camera on me. Dreams would be an interesting place to start, since you're already having vivid ones. I haven't tried it, but I have heard that writing down your dreams helps you to remember more of them when you wake up. Like, you'll start remembering smaller details from the overall dream. I can't lie \-\- I did laugh at the term "suicide jail" because it's a *really* good way to describe it. It's awful that we have to hide our pain because we're scared of being forcibly locked up. It's very counter\-intuitive and just leaves more people hurting for longer than they need to. If you do approach your psychs about the topic, be very specific that you do not have *any* plans or preparations. Also, remember that they're working for *you.* You're the client. You do not owe them anything and if you're not happy with the way that your treatment is progressing, then you are completely within the right to find someone who works better for you.

As someone who does self harm, I'd encourage you to not start. Of course, I read that kind of advice before I started and didn't heed it. You think it will go well and it just doesn't. Other methods than cutting also have their own risks. There is no safe way to self harm. If you're into the pain, one of the best things is holding an ice cube or rubbing it over areas where you self harm. It fulfills the need to cause pain or sensation while also doing no permanent damage. If it's the marks that you're after, then I have a slightly unconventional suggestion. (And hopefully not one that will get me reported. Mods, if you're reading this, I'm still trying to get a grip of where the line is regarding this sort of topic!) Get a dip pen set. They're sold at craft stores and are generally from $10\-12 USD. They come with a bunch of nibs and a holder or two. I like to use the sketching nibs ([like these](https://www.speedballart.com/our-product-lines/speedball-drawing-lettering/speedball-pen-nibs/speedball-pointed-crowquill-pen-nibs/)) versus the calligraphy nibs. Dip the pen into some red food dye and make your marks. Don't press down hard \-\- remember this is an *alternative to self harm.* The marks will stay for several days at the very least before washing away. You can take rubbing alcohol and scrub them off, as well.

You will have a very bad time, but will most likely not die. But you're going to be very, very sick and probably wind up in the hospital. It's possible that Prozac just doesn't work for you. It happens. Another possibility is that it hasn't had enough time to fully kick in if you haven't been on it for long. The way that SSRIs work is that they give you back more energy *before* they start improving mood. That's why the medications have a black box warning.

WRITING.TITLE: OCD and self-harm are slowly killing me (heads up for self-harm and EDs)
WRITING.TEXT: First of all, feel free to laugh at this. I know it's illogical and quite silly, but it's the way I attempt to live my life. I have OCD with a strong basis in contamination and fear of illness. About 5 years ago, I developed IBS\-D out of the clear blue sky. I was already scared of vomiting, but then found the joys of just how much it hurts when bile comes into contact with your anus. The IBS also led to an eating disorder. No idea why the hell it started or figured out what triggered it, so I just started restricting food in general Thank God I was fat to begin with because I lost upwards of 150lbs over the course of about a year or so. It's bad enough that I'm down to rice crackers and Ensure. The magical thinking of the OCD took the IBS and ran with it to it illogical end, to say the least. I also have pretty much zero ways to express or even process mental or emotional pain. I missed that lesson as a kid, so the only coping mechanisms I have are things that take my mind off of the emotional pain and translate it into physical pain. I also have had a trauma conga sort of childhood with abuse, major people in my life dying, almost being coerced into having unnecessary surgery as a kid, the list of events probably take a good four or five sessions with every therapist I go to who want my history. Okay, with all of that in mind, let's take a look at the problem I am obsessing over today. About two weeks ago, I smashed a 5lb weight on my right calf to get some relief from my brain. It was hard enough to make me double over with pain, but at that moment it was such a release for me. The only way I can describe it is that it's like orgasm. I go out of town on a trip. The area starts to swell and get red, but I figure that it's just because of the way I hit it. It didn't get better on its own. In fact, the area grew and became more and more discolored. I went to the doctor yesterday and he gave me a script for an x\-ray, ultrasound, and for an antibiotic. Somehow I developed cellulitis (a skin infection) from a fucking *bruise*. My peeps, my biggest fear right now is that the antibiotics are going to give me diarrhea. ***That's the entire issue.*** It is so fucking stupid, even I can hardly keep a straight face. Thank you for listening to me whinge. Feel free to comment with your bizarre fears. I promise I will not make fun of them, even if they're really out there. Also, I want to say thank you for making this space. It's good to have somewhere you can go full of people who won't freak out about your mental status.

The way that personality disorders are represented and treated is shameful. Like, I'm sure you feel bad enough about things without some doctor or therapist coming at you with the whole "personality disorders can't be fixed" crap. You can learn how to manage the symptoms, but there's no cookie\-cutter specific treatment plan laid out. I'm not going to say it gets better. I can't tell you that and you don't want to hear that. But, sometimes psychs are wrong. They're only human and mental illness is subjective as hell. For example, I was diagnosed with an entire host of disorders form a scantron test from a psychologist. The disorders included AVPD and Dependent Personality Disorder, both with Borderline features. It took me almost two full years and another therapist to find that I probably have Complex\-PSTD, which has very similar features to BPD.

I feel you. I wish I could just find a place to drug me until I don't care anymore. Like, can we just get a robot to do the hard portions of getting better? That being said, if you've just started taking new medication, it can make you act or feel really weird. For example, about a week after I started Anafranil I was getting rage episodes around 4:00 PM every day. No rhyme or reason for it. At first we thought it was related to blood sugar, but nope, just a weird side effect of my brain trying to process the new drug.

I find them entertaining, but probably because my sense of humor is already dark and twisted. I always picture them coming from someone who's had suicidal ideation before. I don't think I'd be as receptive of someone who's just making them to be popular. I can totally understand why you wouldn't like them and a lot of people don't. It does make light of a very serious topic and that can hurt.

You have no idea. It is like the weirdest place in the world. I actually have a specific shorthand for when my OCD goes beyond logic and just becomes funny. I call it a "nuclear potato". Why? Because one day I had just read about two people in Mexico stealing medical equipment, which included a radiation machine for people with cancer. (I'm pretty sure this is the specific incident) I was washing a potato to make a baked potato and all of a sudden my OCD jumped the shark and put together a weird theory where the potato was radioactive. I actually had to stop what I was doing because I was laughing so hard \-\- it made absolutely zero sense. The incident in Mexico had just happened, the potatoes were already on their or had made it to the store by then, I live nowhere *near* Mexico, and the potato itself was grown in Iowa. Thus, "nuclear potato".

You're not failing her at all. Please remember that. It sounds like this has been really rough on the both of you. If your girlfriend isn't in therapy, it's possible she may benefit from it. Specifically, dialectical behavior therapy (DBT) which aims to help bridge the gaps between logic and emotion while still acknowledging that her emotions ***do*** matter. This always sounds so heartless, but you can't be her everything. I highly doubt that she's doing this on purpose, but she's putting you into a bad spot with your own well being and health. This isn't really what a relationship is supposed to be like. It's a little like when someone is drowning. If someone who doesn't know the correct way to rescue them, then the person who's drowning can inadvertently drag down their rescuer until they're both drowning. It isn't intentional at all, but it can have very poor results. I can go back and forth between extreme emotions like your girlfriend does. I had been tagged with everything I possibly could be tagged with until I had a therapist tell me about Complex PTSD (C-PTSD), which can cause symptoms that mimic a bunch of different illnesses. If she's lived in an environment all her life where she's been mistreated or abused, she most certainly developed some unhealthy coping habits from it. I hope that this helps somewhat.

I'm sorry to hear that your fiance passed. That must have been beyond terrible for you. What you're feeling is fairly normal. You're having flashbacks. They can be triggered by many different things including sounds, scents, and sights. They're scary and take a toll on you, but they should lessen with time. It may be worth looking around for support groups in your area. Your area hospice may have a free support group for people who've lost someone major in their lives.[ Here's a list from the Huffington Post about other resources](https://www.huffingtonpost.com/gloria-horsley/ten-places-grieving-widow_b_8039916.html), on and offline.

I get that. Within a year, my car got into three separate accidents (only one was legitimate and my fault. The other two were from a mack truck swiping the side of my car and then from someone backing into me). Car insurance is god-awfully expensive and even more so if you don't have a spotless driving record. They'll find *anything* to hike up your rates. Is there any way to avoid Father's Day this year? I don't think that this sort of situation would be best played out on a holiday.

I don't know much about Portuguese law, but I think a good place for you to start may be with a domestic violence shelter or agency. I couldn't find anything on Google, but I think that's more to do with my search being in English and not Portuguese. Otherwise, your uncle may be of some help. If you can find a job, even a part time one, that could offset the cost of you staying with him and make life easier.

I think the big thing for me is understanding that I've had chronic thoughts of suicide since I was a little kid. I don't use suicide for attention, but I do have my moments when something goes wrong I mutter "Just kill me now!" to myself. People tend to have an overreaction response and tell me that I need to go to the hospital ASAP or that they will force me there because they're worried about me The other side of the coin, there are people who just assume that I'm joking. I have met two (2) therapists in my life who have had the appropriate reaction: establish whether or not the person has made plans and are about to commit suicide or if they just have suicidal ideation. I felt comfortable enough with them both to tell them if the thoughts were getting worse, and one even volunteered to be with me to go to the hospital if I decided I needed to be committed. It was such a big deal for me at the time because I had never had anyone offer that kind of support. And it was kind of funny because she wasn't a private therapist, but rather worked for my school's counseling services and had many other students that she met with. She had worked inpatient before, so she knew what the difference between the two was.

I'll completely agree with you that the hard times don't really make us all that stronger for them! People will comment on how much I've overcome and it's like, "No, what you're seeing isn't the truth. I go through hell every day because of the shit that has been dumped into my life." Distracting, intrusive thoughts can happen about a lot of things, especially self harm and suicide. If they're coming to you unprompted, remember that they are just thoughts, no matter how real or vivid they may seem (this is so much easier said than done). Most people have the, including "normal" people, but most can see these thoughts as strange and dismiss them. [Here is some reading about the topic if you'd like to learn more.](https://moodsmith.com/intrusive-thoughts/#death) I'm 25, going on 26 this year and I'm having a lot of the same kind of feelings about having no real skills and feeling like a failure because I'm basing my self worth on the accomplishments of others. It feels like I'm too late or everything and that I should give up now before I find myself at 30 thinking the same things about when I was 25.

You are so not alone on this. I think everyone on this board has had something similar happen. Like, right now I'm hanging on because I want to see how the plot for Steven Universe shapes up. Video games are another big one for me. I want to see how Fallout 76 shakes out. And, of course, there's the perpetual clinging onto the fantasy that Valve will make a Half-Life 3.

Try to see if you can distract yourself for 10 minutes and see if the pain is still there. Then, do another 10 and reevaluate. You may be able to hold on. Even if you do self harm, don't think of yourself as a bad person. We all slip sometimes. Stress can bring out our most instinctual ways of coping with pain.

Chronic conditions in kids, teens, and young adults should be illegal. It's so isolating to be that one person in your friends group that can't do xyz because you have some kind of medical issue, mental health issue, or both. If it makes you feel any better, I'm having an issue with an antibiotic that can let C. Diff (a really hard to treat bacterial infection of the gut) take over. It's a super small chance, but if it's going to happen to someone, it's going to happen to me. Because life hates me that much.

First off, the fact that your parents call you "thin as a stick" is *not* cool. You don't deserve that kind of belittlement. If you're eating a bunch of food and not gaining any kind of weight, you may have something like hyperthyroidism, where your metabolism works way too fast. I don't know how old you are, but if you're still in your teens, your metabolism is still going to be all over the place as your body prepares to go into adulthood. As for how to gain a little weight, there are different drinks and foods that will provide some dense calories but aren't unhealthy. It sounds like you're in Europe, so I don't know what the food markets are like where you are, but here in the States you can go into a grocery store and get something like [Ensure](https://ensure.com/nutrition-products), which is a drink that has a lot of calories and also has a bunch of vitamins, minerals, and protein. [Articles like this one may also be of some help to you.](https://www.healthline.com/nutrition/18-foods-to-gain-weight#section19)
If you're on a PC, mods will work just fine. I use Nexus Mod Manager to wrangle the ones I have installed.

I just had this happen to me. Stuck on an endless loading screen when attempting to fast travel. It's probably server hiccups. It been less than a week since the game came out and the patch today was huge.

Honestly, the funniest encounters I've had playing the game are the awkward moments when I bump into another solo player. The one that was the best so far was when I was in the airport for the first time and had been attacked by a lot of Scorched but was on edge the entire time because I kept hearing footsteps from *somewhere.* It wasn't until I heard the sound of the Pip-Boy light turning on that I realized that I wasn't be stalked by a monster or anything, but that there was another player running around in the same area probably just as on edge by my movements. I didn't realize that what I'm picking up is part of general loot. Now I feel like a bit of an ass for clearing the place out. Sorry, random stranger! :V

That sounds like something I'd end up doing. Since the death penalties aren't as bad as they *could* be, I'm pretty much a mercy kind of person. I'll probably end up getting killed at this rate, but hey, someone has to be an optimist.

That friggin sucks. I wonder if it'd be possible to launch an effort to transcribe the tapes among players. Everyone should be able to enjoy the little things that *do* help with world building in the game.

Yeah, I was pleasantly surprised that I was able to play the game on day 1 without any huge loading times or crashing. I was fully expecting the servers to be overloaded, but they were pretty damn solid.
Logging off and back in *does* help sometimes. It's useful to avoid ground zeroes for nuclear blasts, too.
Sounds accurate for DMVs in general. Half the fun is experienced in those "OH, SHIT THEY'RE AFTER ME!" moments.

I've found that when I think or utter "I want to kill myself," what I really want is for whatever bad thing is happening to just stop happening. Now, that isn't to say that I've never been suicidal, but a lot of it was just short hand for another emotion. This may be what you're trying to express. Another example for me is that I'll utter "I just wanna go home!" even when I *am* home. What I really mean is that I don't feel safe in a situation and want to feel safe. I don't think that I can be much help about the low self esteem issue. I'm going face to face with that on a daily basis.

It's extremely understandable to feel the way you feel about this. To put it lightly, this is actually a really fucked up situation. You are *not* responsible for your parents' happiness. This isn't because of something that you did and you cannot make this situation better by yourself. Whatever happens, you are not at fault. I think that it may be a good time to reach out to a trusted adult: maybe a teacher, a councilor, or a friend's parent and let them know what you found on your dad's phone.

I go through this. For me, it's a part of my struggle to learn how to regulate my emotions. It's not really "normal" to be swinging so far from one emotion to the other, but it is a thing. A lot of people are dealing with it. What I've personally noticed is that it's a hormonal thing with me. When I'm on my period, it's like being on a [pendulum ride](https://youtu.be/a9tde1ifR_0?t=21). When I'm not on my period, it tends to go between a hammock to a regular playground swing.

The best way to deal with my anxiety is to know what it feels like right before I start to get anxious. If I can figure out what's happening, then I can sort of control it. Or at the very least mitigate the effects. For example, sometimes I get anxious when I'm out shopping. I've noticed that two things in particular tend to ramp up that response: crowds and noise. So if I'm in a place with a lot of crowds and noise, I'm alert to how I'm feeling. Is my breathing picking up? Do I feel my heart racing? Etc. I lose words when I'm having a panic attack. I know what I want to say but it just won't come out of my mouth. When I get to that point, I tend to remove myself from the situation that's causing the anxiety and wait it out for a few minutes. I find that fidget toys help me, as do stupid apps on my phone like Buzzfeed. Going back to that example, I'd get myself out of where I was in the middle of a crowd, take my headphones out of my bag and put them in my ears. Now I've dampened the noise and have moved away from other people, the amount of adrenaline in my body will slowly lower with time. The ultimate goal is to get yourself calm enough to go back into the situation. Unfortunately, you're not doing yourself any favors just avoiding things. But you can work your way up through it. I hope this makes some sense!

This is highly relatable. I wish I knew the way out of this pit because I'd gladly help you. The people say that money can't buy you happiness has never lived in poverty. It's a self-perpetuating system.

WRITING.TITLE: "Just move away from your parents!"
WRITING.TEXT: You probably want to hear my sob story as much as I want to tell it -- not at all. I'm just feeling frustrated because my friends' consensus is that I'd recover from my mental illnesses much better if I moved away from my somewhat abusive parents. Which I agree with. I would probably be less stressed if I did not live with them. The problem is that I am not stable enough to live completely on my own. There are other complicating factors, like the fact that I take 9 different prescription medications throughout the day (my body hates me as well). I can't really guarantee that I'll be able to get my meds if I'm couch surfing or if I suddenly decide to move cross country. The biggest hurdle is that I have a piss poor grasp of basic emotional regulation because of mentioned child abuse. I really don't want to end up in a psychiatric ward, hospital, or jail in the event that I have a meltdown that scares other people (I don't hurt others, but sometimes self-harm because it takes the extreme feelings away). I love my friends, but it comes down to the fact of "Well, I did it (under a completely different set of circumstances), so you should do it too!"

Thank you for responding. I appreciate it. :) I'd love to move out of my parents house within the next year. I've been formally diagnosed with: General Anxiety Disorder, Major Depressive Disorder, Obsessive Compulsive Disorder, Complex Post Traumatic Stress Disorder, Specific Phobia, Avoidant Personality Disorder, and Dependent Personality Disorder. Now that's just one of those scantron things that some psychologists do. I'd say my biggest battles are with OCD, Depression, and C-PTSD. Right now, I'm kinda stuck in place. I used to live alone when I was off in college. I hit a mental rough spot and had to come home. I've been living home for 2 years now and in that time my psychical health went to heck for a while. Things are sticky for the simple fact that I can't work a full time job, but I still need healthcare. My family makes no where near enough money to qualify for the health insurance subsidies and Florida is one of the states that didn't expand Medicaid. So, the only way I can get Medicaid is if I'm deemed disabled by the state. This really sucks because I have a ridiculously low limit to how much I can even own (in my case, no more than \~$500 USD in any kind of bank account). My parents love me and want to protect me, but it's turned into a toxic situation. I love them, but I'm smothered. I'm going to take my next therapy session to see what is out there for people like me. Thank you for taking the time to reply. It means a lot. I'm feeling better this morning.

gt; I can #8217;t even masturbate in peace. I have been there and it is the *worst*. So embarrassing for everyone. Are you talking about buying your own apartment or just renting one? I'm basing this on living in the US, but here you only need like first and last month's rent and a security payment. So the total costs would be maybe something like maybe $2,000 USD to rent your own place up front and then maybe something like $1,000 USD per month for rent. I'm antsy to get out of my parents' place, too. I lived in an apartment in college and it was amazing to be able to do what you want when you want.

I routinely traumatize my friends with stories from my childhood by accident. And I won't know what'll set off someone until I blunder into it. Thus, my friends from bad families don't get to hear as many stories as my friends from good families because I could elicit a PSTD type flashback. Which leaves me in the odd situation that everyone who can emphasize with me cannot deal with me sometimes because of their own mental health concerns while I can talk to people who haven't had those experiences but they often don't understand the trauma. I've traumatized therapists, too. I think it's the blase attitude because I don't have a working schematic of what children go through.

The eye twitching could be related to stress or the lack of caffeine. See if you can notice any patterns in it like what time of day it happens and things like that. Stress and using electronics and bring about eyestrain which will give you a low grade headache. Objectively, Benedryl isn't the *worst* thing you can be taking, but it's bad to get into the habit of going "Oh, I *need* to take something for my anxiety." Here and there it's okay, but not every day or more than one time a day. Learn from my mistakes on that one. When my anxiety gets to be bothersome, I try to immerse myself in something until I eventually forget what I was anxious about (the one decent thing about having anxiety and ADHD tendencies at the same time). Going to therapy may be a good idea. The hardest part is finding someone you like and trust, but it's good to hear perspective from a professional. They can teach you things like how to ride out your waves of anxiety or other coping skills. If all of that doesn't work, giving psych meds a try may be an option. They can make a world of difference, especially when combined with therapy, but they can be a pain in the ass to go off of.

My dad is trying to tell me the same thing. I don't know what to do because he's got me paranoid that if I start asking questions, the state will start to question whether or not I'm disabled. I am disabled and I *need* that status to keep my health insurance so that I can keep taking my medications. Let me know if you've had any luck finding any information. You're not alone in this one.

It depends a *lot.* Medications can really help, but they all have side effects and it can take a while to find the medication (or medications) that works for you. It may not be the first medication you try or you may have to try taking a few different ones. Pick a psychiatrist who you feel comfortable going to. A good psych will weigh the benefits and options and will listen to you when you report side effects. They can help you feel better, but they aren't like taking antibiotics for an infection. Right now, there's no real way to cure mental illness. But they can help you cope a lot better. I've been on meds most of my life and while I don't particularly *like* taking them, I do like how I'm able to function while I'm on them. The one thing that I wish I had known before starting on a medication is that sometimes you'll feel *worse* for a few weeks. This is because the medication increases your energy levels first before lifting your mood. It's normal and something you should talk to your doctor about if you're worried. Generally, this effect is found most in teens and young adults.
It happens to all of us at one time or another! I'd say wait until your next dose. You *may* feel a little weird or have some breakthrough symptoms, but it shouldn't set you back any.

Generally, the point between normal functioning and needing help is drawn when something is impeding on your everyday life. Since it is affecting you, then you should get help. You don't need to be 100% positive that you have depression in order to seek therapy if you want it. You may actually be ahead of things because it's a lot easier to bounce back from things when you're not too bad than it is when you hit rock bottom. Just make sure that you make it explicit that you're having suicidal *thoughts* and not actually planning suicide. Some professionals can be a little jumpy around the topic. As for where to find someone, I've used [Psychology Today's listings](https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/therapists). Go with your gut feeling and always remember that your therapist is working for you. It's fine to switch providers if you don't click with someone.

I'm sorry you feel like you have to hide your struggles That tends to be pretty isolating in and of itself. I can understand why you'd want to keep something like this private depending on what your field is. I've found good fortune through using the [Psychology Today therapist listings](https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/therapists). You can narrow the search by a bunch of different qualifiers and hopefully find someone who you can work with. Most insurance plans will cover both therapy and medication and all health insurance now has to cover mental health. I don't think it's legal for an insurance company to report to your workplace. I am pretty sure that is a violation of the Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (more commonly known as HIPAA). But, you can definitely pay out of pocket for treatment if that's really how you want to go. Rates vary between people and most places have a sliding scale pricing. I'd take a look at [Good RX](https://www.goodrx.com/) for medication pricing. Most of the common medications shouldn't be *that* much money, but make sure to ask for the generic. As for getting ads, I suggest using your browser's private mode. Firefox has a Private Browsing mode and Google Chrome has Incognito mode. Both of these will make sure that you aren't collecting cookies from sites and should make sure that you don't have ads popping up.

Medication has helped me. Right now I'm on Paxil and Anafranil. They aren't magic, but they do make my brain calm down to a level where I can do normal things without a heck of a lot of energy being sucked from my soul. Antidepressants aren't addictive in the same way that benzos are. I can totally understand why you'd be scared to start meds if you've only ever had Valium. I would definitely talk with your therapist and let them know how you're feeling. They'll have a better idea of what will help you. As far as the weed goes, there's not enough information out there. Since it's still illegal federally, there aren't a lot of studies that look at weed and its interactions with other medications. I'd urge caution when combining them with any kind of mental health med. The same goes for alcohol. I hope this helps a little!

I feel you on that one. People who say "Money doesn't buy happiness" have *never* been poor. Yeah, it can't buy happiness, but it can buy food, shelter, and security. Those things are kind of important, too. #8203;

I've had that one paired with "Well, EVERYONE thinks that at one point or another." It's minimizing someone's pain and placing the burden of fortune on that person. Some people are just dealt a shit hand. You've gone through more than a lot of people, even if it doesn't seem that way. Of *course* that's going to influence how you think about yourself!

That's terrible. I'm sorry that you had such incompetent doctors who just made your problems worse. You should really think about filing some kind of lawsuit or report the doctor for malpractice. I know that most people are going to think that the topic if sunny or absurd, but that's really not the case. This is a real pain for you and it does deserve respect. I can understand why you feel like your life is over because that's really quite fucked up.

For me, I don't think that I'll "win" against my depression. That's as absurd to say "I won against diabetes." I have times where I don't have as many symptoms, but it's not something that's going to go away entirely. I was exposed to complex trauma as a kid and got myself wired wrong. My mind doesn't work the way other people's do. Although, I have something closer to dysthymia or "chronic depression" than one singular episode of depression. Speaking honestly, I become incredibly envious of people who've "beaten" it because it's not an option for me. It almost strikes me as arrogant. I wish my story was as simple as "I had depression, but therapy and medication have fixed my problem." Mine's more or less "I had a panic disorder as a child and as I've gotten older I've just grown that garden and accumulated diagnoses like other kids collected baseball cards." I think I'm up to like 8 now. #8203;

One way to bump me into anger quickly is to say to me or other people "Well, you/they're not getting better because you/they don't *want* to get better." Like, excuse me? You really think we're getting a lot out of being miserable? Do you really think that if it was that easy we would still be suffering? Do you think this is some fun little game we're playing? It's fucking *hard*, especially if you're still expected to carry out all of your normal tasks and responsibilities. It's hard regardless!

These are *not* your best years, trust me on that. Neither are your college years. Don't get yourself locked into that mindset because it doesn't do anything but make you more miserable because you're comparing your life to this idealistic one that doesn't exist.

Okay, I'd love to be able to go and kick your psychiatrist's ass. This is *not* on you. I've had a mental health professional give up on me and it took me *years* to understand that that was *her* problem, not mine. She wanted an easy case where I'd be able to go through a course of CBT and be completely in remission. She saw me as a problem to solve and not a person. She told me that I would *never* get better without *months* of inpatient treatment. You know what? She was wrong. Psych medications are so complex and hard to get right. Like, it's hard to treat just depression. It's harder to treat depression, anxiety, and OCD at the same time. It can feel like the moment you put out one fire, another one sparks. I have OCD, too, and wouldn't wish it on my worse enemy. It is such a disabling condition. Right now I'm in a better place than I was, but I still struggle to get through things sometimes. Definitely switch providers. Another doctor may have some ideas on what can help. If you haven't already tried tricyclic antidepressants, you may want to give one a go. I was prescribed Anafranil a few years ago and it's helped me to stay steady. I'm so sorry that you've been put through this. You are far from alone in this.

This is *totally normal*. It's called "antidepressant discontinuation syndrome." Basically, your body has gotten used to the medication and when you go off of them your body is like "What the fuck? EMERGENCY TIME!" It is often mistaken for a relapse because it causes symptoms that look like depression or anxiety disorders. All psych medications need to be weaned off of. Stopping it cold turkey is *not* a fun time, as you've experienced. [Here's some more information about it from Harvard](https://www.health.harvard.edu/diseases-and-conditions/going-off-antidepressants). Your psychiatrist *should* have told you about this when you first started taking medication, but some just don't.

I don't think it's a *bad* decision, no. Whether or not you take medication isn't a morality choice. If you feel like they are not working for you or if you feel that the side effects outweigh the benefits, then by all means stop taking them. You just have to make sure you taper or you'll probably get some withdrawal effects. Doing it under a doctor's care is best, but I know people who've tapered off on their own. It's a slow process, though. I'd do it little by little. For example, I'm on Paxil and I have been for nearly 20 years. If I wanted to go off of it, I'd start very slow. I'm on 40mg, so I'd lower it by 5mg for a few weeks, then 30mg for a few weeks, and so on. You don't have to do it *that* slow if you haven't been on the medication a long time. You may be able to decrease it to something like 3/4 of your dose to begin with.
Unfortunately. It's... interesting being me.

No problem. I'll list what I've been "officially diagnosed" with, or the things that I've had various psychologists and psychiatrists have pegged me with. Keep in mind I've been in the system for 20 years at this point. Generalized Anxiety Disorder (GAD) Obsessive Compulsive Disorder (OCD) Major Depressive Disorder (Depression) Persistent Depressive Disorder (Dysthmia) Specific Phobia (Phobia of vomiting) Panic Disorder (Panic attacks) Depersonalization/Derealization Disorder Avoidant Personality Disorder with Borderline features Dependent Personality Disorder with Borderline features Now, that's what I've been explicitly *told* I've had and I don't agree with all of the diagnoses. There's also been talk about Borderline Personality Disorder, Bipolar disorder and ADHD. The reason why I have so many diagnoses is because I tick a lot of boxes for a *lot* of disorders. But there's a Non-DSM disorder that *does* and that's Complex PTSD (C-PTSD). It's not an "official" disorder yet, but more research is being done on it. With C-PTSD as an option, the list looks more like this: OCD, Depression, Specific Phobia, and C-PSTD. As for how I cope... I think I have a different experience of the world than a lot of people do. A lot of it is trying to keep in mind that everything going through my head is most likely temporary. I have frequent panic attacks and have a harder time bouncing back from hardships, but I'm learning how to manage things with dialectical behavior therapy.

I know *exactly* how you feel. I'm 26 and I feel like I've wasted my life. Things have just gotten harder and harder and I miss how easy things were in high school. Every time my birthday comes around I dread it because it means that it's just another year gone. I think part of it is that we've been fed the lie that your teens and twenties is the best time of you life. I've heard from a lot of people that this isn't true and that if anything things get better over the years. My life right now is better than it was a year ago, so maybe it's true? I hope that it's true for you, too. Just know that you are *totally* not alone in this.

That Hamilton song gets to me, too. It's good that you've been able to cry. It's a release. We've been so conditioned not to show weakness and to keep that happy mask up for people that I think a lot of us don't actually feel our feelings anymore. I really, really hope that you're experiencing a turning point because you *do* deserve it.

Yes! This is definitely a thing that happens. I'm not a professional, but has anyone told you about Bipolar II? Here's what Google says about it: gt;It involves at least one depressive episode lasting at least two weeks and at least one hypomanic episode lasting at least four days. Depressive symptoms include sadness or hopelessness. Hypomanic symptoms include a persistently elevated or irritable mood. Treatment includes counseling and medications, such as mood stabilizers. #8203;

I know this specific kind of pain. You're definitely *not* being a spoiled baby. Teeth are generally seen as important and there are extremely negative stereotypes about people who have bad teeth and/or missing teeth. It's bullshit that dental isn't covered in health insurance plans. It's bullshit that dental work costs a small fortune in general. There may be a dental school in your area and they *should* either have free services or low cost services.

Sassenacho knocked this out of the park on this one. :) Here's the one thing that I wish someone told me when I first started seeking help: Your psychiatrist, psychologist, and/or therapist works for *you.* If you don't mesh with someone, it's totally normal to find a different person. It's hard to talk about what's going on in your head and it's important that you feel safe and secure with the people you're seeking help from. 1. There isn't a general kind of sheet of official diagnoses or anything. There *are* tests, but most of the time they're given orally and the patient doesn't see any kind of readouts. It's not like drawing blood and other lab work (I wish it was that simple, though!). 2. She may not have enough information about you yet. You *can* request any of the notes that she took while you were talking with her and they may have more information. I think she's trying to test the waters and float the idea of mental illness in your direction to see how you'll react. 3. You totally don't need to try an SSRI if you don't feel comfortable with the idea. You sound like you're functioning fairly well, so therapy alone may do it for you. Psych meds are more like tools than miracles. They may help you cope with your symptoms and are not mandatory. 4. Getting a second opinion is always a good thing. If you what to and have the means to go to another professional for another evaluation, do it. If you feel like you can cope without the medications, I'd try therapy. CBT is a good start, but other forms may also help you. The biggest thing is going to be finding a therapist to help lead you through this journey. I hope this helps!

That can happen with medication. Normally, it settles down at the 6-8 week mark. But, if you really feel like you can't take it, talk to your doctor. Sometimes a different medication in the same category will work better for you or cause you less side effects. When I was first put on Anafranil (older antidepressant), I had daily episodes of rage for the first few weeks before my body adjusted to the medication. Now it's smooth sailing in that regard.

What you're experiencing has now been labeled "Antidepressant discontinuation syndrome." [Here's a link to more information about it](https://www.health.harvard.edu/diseases-and-conditions/going-off-antidepressants). As for how long the brain zaps last, it seems to be dependent on how long you've been on the medication. Since you were only on it for nine months, it'll probably last for a few weeks to months, getting less severe over time. One of the key traits to distinguish the discontinuation syndrome from another mental illness is that the symptoms will stop fully with taking the medication. The relief typically comes within 24 hours. I hope that your cases go well!

It's great when you make strides, but it always seems so delicate and you're always afraid of messing up and sliding back down. You get better at it as time goes on. It becomes less of a constant effort and more of a natural reaction. It's like lifting weights; you will eventually become stronger and the weight of this moment will feel lighter. You'll have missteps and rough times (because of external factors) and that's normal. My big measuring stick is "Is this feeling so important that it's worth undoing everything over?" Most of the time my answer is no. Sometimes, my answer is yes. When it's yes, I give myself some time to calm down and then reassess.

The system here *is* really fucked up. Has withdrawal from olanzapine come up? I've never experienced it, but I know it'll make people *really* sick, both physically and mentally. [Here's a link to more information on withdrawal](https://www.withdrawal.net/learn/antipsychotic/). If it *is* withdrawal, then giving her a dose of the olanzapine will "fix" what's going on here. Psych wards aren't the most fun place to be. She'll be separated from you and you'll have to work from the outside to make sure that she's getting the care she needs. Personally, I found that it worsened my condition, but it all depends on the person and the facility. I can't guarantee anything. Some places are great, some places are pretty damn sucky. If you or she has ever been inpatient in a hospital, it's kind of like that but with a lot more locks on doors and more restrictions on what you can or cannot do. [Here's a decent overview of what to take and what to expect.](https://share.upmc.com/2017/05/inpatient-psychiatric-stay/) Some things will happen regardless, like being separated from family members/friends/loved ones (you're not going to be able to go with her). Just as a warning, they may end up strip searching her, so she should prepare for that. It took me off guard on the day I was admitted. They're looking for scars (particularly self-harm scars). I hope she's feeling better soon!
No problem. I'm glad I can help.

First of all, it's great that you took a shower! Things like that should get a little easier when you get your energy back. From what I understand, with SSRIs you get your energy back before you start feeling a lifted mood. That's why there are all those warnings about thoughts of suicide and such. If someone is deep into that hole, sometimes taking the meds give them enough energy to attempt it before things get better. What you're going through is likely a combination of side effects from the medication as your body adjusts to it and realizing that you may have a worse problem than you thought you have. If you want, calling the doctor that prescribed you the medication wouldn't be a bad idea. They'll have much more knowledge than most of us here do and it's good to keep them updated on effects. But yes, it takes a few weeks for everything to settle down inside your brain. Be watchful for any drastic changes in mood (almost to where you feel like you don't have control) and if that happens, definitely get in touch with your doctor. I hope that everything evens out for you soon and that your treatment will work!
No problem! Best of luck with your C-PTSD. It's a beast to try to get a handle on.

I wish I could tell you how to fix self hate, but I'm in the middle of it myself. I've found that helping other people has actually been a helpful way to cope. It's a small way of going, "Well, at least I did xyz for someone today." It doesn't have to be big things. It can be as simple as just saying hello to someone or giving directions to tourists or even just holding the door. Try not to start cutting. I know that everything hurts and that pain can feel *really* good, but it makes sometimes it makes it harder for yourself down the road. If you want to feel pain, hold on to an ice cube or stick your hand in icy water. This will cause pain sensation, but won't do any harm. I wouldn't do it for an extended period of time, but it may help to release the same endorphins. If you want to self harm because you want a mark of some sort (like a way to signal to people "I'm feeling horrible" or as a way of externalizing your symptoms), then a marker can be helpful. Again, it won't cause any physical harm, but it'll still allow you that record of your pain. Those are the two most common substitutes. But, if you're up for it, doing something else all together to distract you will also help. Play a video game, color, watch TV, listen to music. Anything that will put some time between your urge and a potential action. Most of the time you'll find that after a while, the urge will lessen. Your body eventually relaxes and stops producing as many chemical signals that create things like panic attacks. I hope that this helps, at least a bit.
No problem. Take care of yourself.

I think it comes from feeling like you're not worth being kind to. Or, at least that's where it comes from for me. I'm still not good at positive self-talk (bleh, therapy terms) when I'm feeling bad. I either get really sad and start crying or I get pissed off. When I'm okay it's easier. I find that trying to talk to yourself from a neutral outside position gives me some comfort. Like, I can't stand hearing self-affirming messages when it's me talking to myself. But, I've found that if I can imagine my favorite character saying those things to me it actually helps to put it in perspective.

Giving your knife to your aunt may not seem like a big deal, but it's an excellent first step. It sounds to me like you're feeling unheard. That can really mess with you because eventually you start to think that you just don't matter. It's not a matter of doing it "for attention" like that's something that doesn't matter. Because it *does* matter. We're wired to *need* a base level of attention and communication. Is it possible to talk to your aunt about these things? Or at least about feeling ignored?

I'm glad that you have your aunt and I'm sorry that your parents are less than stellar. I'm not sure how old you are, but I can say that getting into a different home environment can be an immense help. It's sometimes daunting, but it's much better than being under control of people who don't care what is happening with or to you. Trying to get a therapist without your parents contributing is hard. I've had a friend like that. I think you may get a lot out of something like 7 Cups. If you haven't heard of it before, it is a site where you can talk to people who have been through a training program for free. They're called listeners. They also provide 1-on-1 therapy with therapists. The therapy does cost money, though. I haven't used the service myself, so I don't know how they react to self-harm and/or thoughts of suicide. But you're anonymous on there, so no one can call the police on you or anything. https://www.7cups.com Keep strong.

Yes. It is *so* wrapped up in my self-loathing. Like, when therapists and psychs are like, "Don't you want to be nice to your inner child?" And it's like FUCK NO. I don't know why it's such a visceral and instant reaction. You're totally not alone on this, though.

The head slamming thing always seems like a great idea in the moment, but really is just a train to concussionville. I don't even *want* to know how much I've messed myself up by doing it since I was a kid, but I do have a slipped disc in my neck for the efforts. Srsly, people, don't start with the self harming because it's not glamorous or fun.

WRITING.TITLE: Anyone dealing with this 20+ years from childhood?
WRITING.TEXT: **Note: Please don't stop your medication because of this post. I'm not going to stop mine, but I do want to hear from people who have had a similar experience.** Hey, has anyone else been deemed "mentally ill" when they were under 10 and put on medication? I've been taking Paxil (40mg/day) since I was 6. I was also on Trazodone from the ages of 6 to 10. I was diagnosed with both Generalized Anxiety Disorder and Depression when I was 6. Anyone else wonder if these antidepressants affected your growing brain in ways you don't know? It's like "Huh. I wonder what I'd be like if I wasn't on psych meds as a kid..." ETA: Here's some information that I found, if all y'all are curious. ["Should Children Take Antipsychotic Drugs?" Scientific American, 3/1/14](https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/should-children-take-antipsychotic-drugs/) ["Why Are Doctors Giving Anti-Psychotic Drugs to Toddlers" New York Magazine, 2017](https://www.thecut.com/2017/04/why-are-doctors-giving-anti-psychotic-drugs-to-toddlers.html) ["Effects of Stimulants and SSRIs on Brain Function in Children: Emerging Clues from fMRI Studies" Pubmed, 2011](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3640815/)

I feel the same way. It's like, I'm glad that the medication seems to do *something*, but I really wish we knew more about long time use. It's sadly becoming more and more common for kids to be taking psychiatric drugs. I've heard of *toddlers* being prescribed these things now. ([Here's a medical journal article talking about the amount of kids being put on SSRIs, lowest age was 3.](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3640815/)) Antidepressants have been used this way for a long while (since around 2000), but more kids are being put on anti-psychotics, which can *really* heck you up because they're more powerful. They're generally used to keep people calm and anti-combative. They're [used to tame aggression](https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2015/07/01/418935734/antipsychotics-too-often-prescribed-for-aggression-in-children), but [a lot of the kids who are on them are Autistic](https://www.thecut.com/2017/04/why-are-doctors-giving-anti-psychotic-drugs-to-toddlers.html). It's like "whoa, let's maybe teach kids better coping mechanisms first." Therapy can be hard for kids, but oof. I don't think I'll be coming off of them any time soon. I don't know if it actually does anything, but I don't want to go through withdrawal. Although, I can say that another antidepressant I just started two years ago (Anafranil) has done pretty good at keeping my OCD at bay.

It probably would have been in the vein of learning how to step back and deal with my emotions. Or something like Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (CBT). I had a rough and tumble childhood (family dysfunction, losing loved ones at a young age, etc.) and the meds were tried really early because everyone around me wanted me to calm down. This was about the turn of the century, before they had the black box warnings on SSRIs for kids and the risk of suicidal thoughts. Paxil, the drug I was placed on, isn't used in kids anymore because it was shown to be [ineffective at best and dangerous at wors](https://www.medicinenet.com/script/main/art.asp?articlekey=23694)t. It has more interactions with different medications, too.

This is actually a thing that happens. People, even professionals, assume that if you're putting at least *some* effort into your appearance that you cannot *possibly* be as depressed as you are. It's a terrible stereotype that hurts a lot of people. It's not fair that you're put through abuse by your dad and then no one believes it when you tell them that everything is not fine. You shouldn't have to have to prove to anyone that you're not okay. And it's not fair that you're feeling left behind by friends. That's a shitty situation any way you slice it. Being frank with people may be a decent tactic to go for in this case. Acknowledge that even though you may look okay, you certainly don't feel that way.

It's possible that you may be a little scared to be or that you're feeling hesitant to let yourself feel good. Sometimes it's also hard to actually let yourself get better because you've assimilated your depression into a core part of your personality. When you live with it for a long time, it becomes second nature. Try to not let the urge to fall back push you back. It *should* pass given enough time. If it makes you feel any better, I've been in the same spot. For me it was a bit like "Leave me alone to wallow in my self-loathing and pain!"

If you haven't already looked into it, you may be interested in something called Dialetical Behavior Therapy or DBT. A chunk of that therapy is dedicated to making and putting in place a crisis plan full of techniques that will help you survive the moment. This can include anything from sensory input like physically cooling yourself off to self-soothing with a distraction. Basically, anything that'll keep you around long enough to come back down from that breaking point to where you feel more normal. [Here's a guide to distress tolerance skills](https://www.sunrisertc.com/distress-tolerance-skills/). [And here's another one](https://thingofthings.wordpress.com/2015/09/08/dbt-sequence-crisis-survival/). There are also some apps on both iOS and Android that can help you use these kinds of strategies. Just search for "DBT."
The people who say "Money can't by happiness" has no idea what it's like to stare down a bank account with $20, three bills due, and a week to payday.

I've found that this works really well for me. I don't keep any razor blades in the house because when I did (I'm an artist and they're useful for cutting things) I was much more tempted to use them on myself. I find that if I can let the feeling pass, then I'm okay.

You could also see someone else. Your therapist is supposed to be there for you to hear you out. It sounds like the one you have now may be devaluing everything you have to do and the critical position that you're in. You have a *ton* on your plate. Don't feel like you're obligated to see this one person. People switch therapists all the time. Sometimes you don't click with a person or their therapy style isn't right for you.

For the camera, I'd set it on automatic and just take photos. A ton of them. They don't need to look good or be your best work, just so long as you're taking photos. Two years is a good long while and it makes perfect sense that it's not going to come back fully the instant you pick your gear up again. You know how sometimes you pick up a pen and scribble with it and it takes a bit of scribbling to get the ink to come back out? It's exactly like that. Sometimes you just need to get all of that crap out of the way to be able to make things you like. As you get better with it, you can switch into other modes. MrBioTendency also makes a good point: a lot of cameras are *way* over-complicated these days. Getting used to a new system takes some time especially since the manufacturers seem to constantly be switching controls and button combinations. I can't really answer your question to get the images of people you would let down out of your head. I do the same things: push people away over and over again with the intention of getting to the point where nobody loves me. It has been miserable when I do it because I come to ache for company, but no one is there.

That is quite the situation. For right now, you may not want to get drunk or high. It may be best to keep yourself firmly to the ground while you stabilize. Just getting through today is your main goal. Take care of your leg, too. I've had times when I've accidentally hurt myself during a panic, too. It does suck that you do have to go to work while you feel like hell. You have a few options, but I think your best bet is to talk to your therapist and tell him or her what happened if you feel comfortable doing so. You do want to keep in mind that if they think you are a danger than yourself, they may push you to go to the hospital as an inpatient. That *might* help. It will certainly keep you in a confined area and away from physical harm, but it's probably not the best idea if you cannot take time off of work because you could be stuck in there anywhere from a day or two to a few weeks. If you do want to go that route, you'll want to look up the hospital(s) near you to see what kind of services there are and to read reviews. Another option is to tell your therapist that you've been thinking about suicide, but make it clear that you don't have any plans to actually do it. That *usually* hits the right spot between "I'm fine." and "I'm a danger to myself." It's in "I'm not okay and need some help." territory. You don't have to go through this alone.

Antidepressants can cause that effect, especially within the first few weeks of taking them. They're altering your brain in a very literal sense, so they're likely to make things go wonky for a while. You should tell your psychiatrist first thing when they open for the week. They may switch you to another medication that is more easily tolerated. The way I've heard it described is that anidepressants will often increase your energy before they increase your mood, so if you're suicidal it sounds like a *really* good idea in the moment. These weeks are probably going to be the hardest of it. I know that a few weeks seems like a lifetime. Do whatever you need to do to at least hold on for a little longer. If you're up for it or want to hold out for a bit of hope, [here's a guide to crisis management](https://www.sunrisertc.com/distress-tolerance-skills/). It's meant for people with Borderline Personality Disorder, but it's geared for the moments where we're white-knuckling it. When I was first put on to one of my antidepressants, I spent the first few weeks between distraught, near mania, and an all encompassing rage. All of these daily very extreme emotional swings went away as my body started to get adjusted to the medication. It was a physical side effect. Give it at least a few days and then reassess. There's at least a small chance that you'll be in a different state of mind.

If you were physically ill with a life threatening condition, you would go to the ER, right? This isn't too much different at all. Admitting this shit is the first step towards a life that has a better outlook. A *lot* of people struggle with mental health issues, probably more people in your life than you know about. We're told to keep it under wraps because it still feels almost like a moral failing. Don't let your fear of the stigma to get in between you and help. Trust me when I say that a lot of people will understand. I know I've been flinging this link out a lot, but [here are some coping skills](https://www.sunrisertc.com/distress-tolerance-skills/) that you might find useful during a white-knuckle moment. The big aim of them is to basically get you calmed down a little bit before you make a decision that you may not have made if you had been in another state of mind.

Unfortunately, a lot of the psych drugs *do* have withdrawal symptoms when stopped. Most of the time, the amount of issues you may have relate to the amount of time you've taken it. If you're on the drugs for years then you'll have a harder time than someone who's only taken it for a few weeks. It's always very important with any psych meds to do a gradual taper when getting off of them or switching from one to the other. Your psychiatrist should be more than willing to give you a straight answer on things. This is a reasonable concern and you do deserve to have your concerns taken seriously.

I'm sorry that this has been happening to you. What you describe sounds like an anxiety or panic attack. It's basically your fight-or-flight instinct being suddenly activated and your body gets into a very excited, tense state. They can make you anxious about having another one which just feeds back into itself. [Here's some more information](https://moodsmith.com/panic-disorder/). The good news is that they're pretty dang common and there are ways to help get yourself back down to a more grounded state. [This article](https://www.healthline.com/health/how-to-stop-a-panic-attack) has some of the more common coping methods. The thoughts you're experiencing sound a lot like intrusive thoughts, which is basically another name for "very uncomfortable thoughts that won't get out of your head." These are also pretty common. With intrusive thoughts, the big thing to remember is that just because you *think* something doesn't mean that you're going to act on it. For example, when I was going through a rough patch I kept having thoughts about killing my dog. It freaked me out because I adored my dog and would never have wanted to cause him harm. The thoughts can go hand-in-hand with a panic attack with one leading to another. [Here is some good information on intrusive thoughts](https://moodsmith.com/intrusive-thoughts/).
No problem. I hope you're in a better place today.

Part of it is because there are such strong stigmas against certain disorders, even among psych professionals. For example, someone who is diagnosed with Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) is going to have a hell of a time finding treatment because so few people want to take on Borderline clients. People with BPD are seen as dramatic bothers who will do nothing but back stab, suck up the air, and refuse treatment. Those are just harmful stereotypes. For the most part a lot of it is just trying to get through life while having our emotions set up like a roller coaster. It actually took me a hell of a long time to get help because everyone was like, "You're too *nice* to have BPD!" Pro tip: If anyone else has been seen as "too nice" for a BPD dx and if you've had trauma in your past, try for a Complex PTSD (C-PTSD) diagnosis. It's all the same symptoms, just packaged in a different label. Another disorder that comes with a plane's worth of baggage is Schizophrenia. It's so bad that they're thinking about renaming it. Although, it is nice to have something as tangible to hold as a diagnosis. I know that when I found out about BPD/C-PTSD I was so relieved because it someone else has been though this. I wasn't going it alone anymore.

Try them out, at least for a little while. They can cause some side effects, but those can be helped by either switching to a different medication and/or letting your body get used to the medication. It's going to mess you up less than the alcohol and/or other drugs will. Just keep in mind that they may increase your energy before they lift your mood, so it's good to let a trusted person know you're taking them so that they can keep an eye on you. The worst of it is in the first few weeks. If it makes you feel any better, I've considered doing the same with the police. I never acted on it, but I can understand the thoughts behind it. I hope that this can be a new beginning for you. You're still young and have time to get things in order.

Nothing about this is fair. It's not fair that your family has all but cut you out or that you've been assaulted or that you're living with so much pain. Anyone who's gone through all of that is going to end up shaken by it. I'm sure you've heard all the advice they can possibly give you in therapy. Inpatient treatment can be kind of shit regarding helping you after you've passed through their care. Please excuse me for assuming your gender (you mentioned about being seen as a brother). Did you go over your sexual assault when you talked to professionals? It sounds like you're really struggling with the way that that has changed you. You're not alone in it nor should you feel like you're worthless. And if you *are* a guy, it doesn't make you any less of a man, y'know? It wasn't your fault. If you've tried a few different treatments and they haven't worked, you may be eligible for the ketimine-related medication that's just been cleared by the FDA for treatment resistant depression. I also remember reading an article when they first started researching it that it can also really help with PTSD. And it's supposed to work fast, too. Within a few days. [Here's a news story about it.](https://www.self.com/story/esketamine-for-depression) It may be worth giving it a shot considering that you've been inpatient a few times and have already attempted suicide. Your doctors should have some kind of idea where you can find either that treatment or a ketamine clinic. I hope that something in this message is useful to you. #8203;

Well, you just told all of us. I can't promise that I'll personally be here to talk to you, but there are usually quite a few people hanging around. I'm sorry you're feeling such an intense nothingness. That void and nothingness is a common symptom of depression called "anhedonia." You're not alone in this. And you're not alone in feeling like you have no future. A lot of people who've grown up with depression have a hard time planning for the future because they don't feel like they'll make it. I had the same feelings when I was your age. I never thought I'd make it to 20, but I'm still here at 26. I'm going to assume that you're from the US just because a lot of people here are from it. Depending on the state you live in, you may be able to seek out therapy or other mental health services without your parents' consent, but in most of them you have to be living away from them. [Here is some information about the age of consent as it regards to medicine](https://www.schoolhouseconnection.org/state-laws-on-minor-consent-for-routine-medical-care/). If you're afraid to talk to your parents about how you've been feeling, or if you feel like you aren't being heard, sometimes it's better to write them a letter explaining how you feel and that you want to seek help. I'm not entirely sure the right way to phrase it, but the National Alliance on Mental Illness (NAMI) has a helpline that you can call to get referrals. [Here's some info on that](https://www.nami.org/Find-Support/NAMI-HelpLine). Another handy site to use is 7 Cups of Tea. It's a mental health focused service where you can vent to someone who'll listen to you. I haven't used the service myself, but I've heard some good things about it. [They have a specific area for teens.](https://www.7cups.com/teen-chat-support/) They're better equipped than I am to walk you through all of this. Finally, [here's a huge list of resources from Mental Illness Mouse](https://mentalillnessmouse.wordpress.com/helpfulresources/). It goes over basically everything you'll need to know about getting help, diagnosis, etc. It's helped me out quite a few times. I hope that you're able to get the help you need.

I'm currently trapped in the Disability hellhole and it is *so* much work and stress to get on the program. People think it's so easy, but it just isn't. Endless mounds of paperwork, doctor's visits, and interviews. Basically everyone who applies gets rejected and appeals can take a long time. So, don't beat yourself up too hard for not getting it approved. It's *designed* to put you through the wringer. It is good that you managed to find a job where you're not doing customer service. It's a lot easier to modulate when you're not forced to interact with rude and demanding customers all day. You may have already tired or heard about this, but Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) can be a huge help in these kinds of situations. It's basically a therapy that helps you wrangle emotions. A good chunk of the therapy is what's called "distress tolerance." Its main focus is to bring your anxiety and emotions back more towards baseline though activating physical senses (touch, smell, sound, etc.). It's best done with a therapist who can help you sort out your emotions more, but the techniques are fairly simple. [Here's some more detail about the techniques for tolerating existence](https://www.sunrisertc.com/distress-tolerance-skills/) when the dark hole opens up suddenly beneath you. Things that you can do are fairly simple like increasing or decreasing your body's temperature and breathing exercises. Personally, I find that making myself cold helps me to bring my focus back to the moment, so during the winter I'll step outside for a few minutes just to get the feeling of the cold air on my face. Then I do breathing exercises. It can really help me to calm down before I do something stupid. If you want/need more information on just about everything to do with mental illness, [here's a huge list of resources that are my own personal go-to.](https://mentalillnessmouse.wordpress.com/helpfulresources/) I hope that you're doing at least a bit better now. Keep holding onto music.

Even the people who are the toughest still have a breaking point. I think that you're ahead of the game because you recognize the drop and the ways it can affect you. It's a lot easier to get out of that hole when it's three feet deep than when it's fifty. You won't be a bother to anyone if you let them know that you haven't been doing well recently. Letting someone in your life in could make you feel a lot better. You don't have to go it alone. That way, they can also keep an eye on you to make sure that you don't sink too far down. You'd do the same for your friend or your partner, right? I'm sure you've been through the ropes as far as self-harm goes. I find that using DBT skills ([like these](https://www.sunrisertc.com/distress-tolerance-skills/)) make it easier to process my feelings more objectively. Most of the time I try to lose myself in an activity I enjoy, like playing video games or making art. Eventually, the feeling passes for me. It may be good to track what kind of symptoms you're having because they could be caused by something physical going on. PMS is one of the major health things that can turn me upside down (I'm not trying to say it's PMS, but hormones play a huge part in how we feel). I hope that you're feeling more like yourself again.

Okay, first off, you are a kickass friend. Just writing all of this up to ask us all must have taken you a long while and it really shows just how much you care for him. The hardest damn part of this is that you can't force someone to seek treatment. I wish that I could tell you the magic words to help your friend see that he \*is\* worth it. This next part of this is hard to say and will be hard to hear: You need to take care of yourself, too. It seems like your friend has had a lot of chances to get the help he needs, but for some reason he isn't reaching out to the resources he has. I've done this myself. I've had all the resources I could have possibly needed, but still refused help. Part of it was because I didn't think I was worth it and part of it was because I kind of liked the pain. I could feel pain on the days when I couldn't feel anything. It's like picking at a scab. It feels unhealthy to be supporting him like this because it is unhealthy. You can't be his only support. Doing what you're doing now is probably unsustainable in the long run and could hurt both of you in the end. Getting out of a hole as deep as your friend is in is hard. It takes a lot of energy and time and understanding to be able to take the steps towards a different future. Your friend may find some hope in the fact that the FDA just approved a new medication for treatment resistant depression. It's a nasal spray that has to be given at the doctor's, but it's supposed to work very quickly. It's possible that the medications that he's on aren't the right ones for him or that he may not be taking them as regularly as he should. Most of the meds we have now take a few weeks to really start working and can raise up your energy before it raises your mood. [Here's a big list of different mental health resources.](https://mentalillnessmouse.wordpress.com/helpfulresources/) I've used it so many times over the years and it's helped in some really rough circumstances.
