It does have some links about BDD, too. I think some of the links under "Helping a friend" would be a good place to start. I'd also look under "Borderline Personality Disorder" (BPD). BPD gets a horrible rep. Basically, it's a combination of different factors such as emotion dysregulation (mood swings) and a difficulty with interpersonal relationships (connecting with other people). People with BPD are often afraid of being abandoned, so they typically either really latch on to people or push people away. I have Borderline tendencies (not "full on" but the experiences ring true) and the first time I understood what was going on in my head was through memes. Years ago, we used to have motivational animals. One that floated my way was the "Borderline Scorpion." I had to laugh at them because they were \*so\* me and it gave me a lot of hope because the swirling thoughts and emotions actually had a name. [Here are the memes](http://borderlinescorpion.tumblr.com/). BPD \*is\* something that you can learn to get a handle on and it's usually treated with Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) and medication. [This link is a really good guide for how to support someone who struggles with BPD](http://betterthandarkchocolate.tumblr.com/post/29746668068/ten-guidelines-for-families-partners-and-friends). It goes through everything from trying to get them help to how to put some boundaries and keep your loved one accountable. Even if your friend doesn't have BPD, it's still handy. I hope that this post helps somewhat. I wish you and your friend the best and I hope that he can see in himself the person who you see he is.
You're welcome. :)

For me, part of it is because of the inspiration porn (using disabled people as a prop for feel good stories), part of it is because the world isn't that easy (for example, it's a lot easy to "let go" of your problems if your life is stable. It's like when people say "Money can't buy happiness" but have never actually been broke), and part of it is pure unbridled envy (I wish my problems were solved that easily). I'd recommend r/wowthanksimcured for the opposite. Some of the time, positivity can work, but sometimes we just need snark to get through the day.

Just keep in mind that psych meds often take a few weeks to get up to start really working. You may feel an increase in energy without an increase of mood at first. So you may feel agitated, angry, or aggressive for seemingly no reason. This side effect should stop within a few weeks. If you have anyone who you are close to and see regularly who you trust with personal information, tell them that you're starting a new medication and ask if they can keep an eye out to see if you're acting weirdly. If you do notice a lot of side effects with your medication, tell your PCP and they can move you to a different medication or help you to safely stop taking them.

WRITING.TITLE: Abused by Psychologist during ERP
WRITING.TEXT: Hi, this is my first time posting on this particular board. Basically, my main question is how do I try to get help for OCD when I was abused by a psychologist who used CBT and ERP against me? I had hit a low point in 2015 where I was so worried about contamination as it regards to germs. Standard stuff. I was washing my hands a lot and it got to the point where I was spending 4-5 hours a day just on trying to find some relief. I knew that CBT and ERP are considered the gold standard for OCD care, so I went to a well known OCD organization to find someone in my area who did those kinds of therapies. Surprisingly, I did find someone near where I was attending college. Long story short, there were quite a few things that went off the rails during treatment. The psychologist treated me with little respect from the first time I met her. I just figured that I deserved to be treated like that and I went to see her weekly for about six months. I'm pretty sure part of her problem with me is that this hadn't been my first time in therapy. I was diagnosed with mental health conditions when I was a child, so I had spent plenty of time in therapy. When I described the dissociative and depersonalization episodes that hit me when I got pushed over the edge, she told me that I was the one that was causing them and that I should stop. I ended up crying (she rolled her eyes at me for that) while trying to explain that no, I didn't *want* to flip into dissociation and that it scared me. She insisted that it was my own doing and that I could easily stop it. She also wanted me to not read any more about OCD or treatments for it, telling me that the only things that I needed to know is what she was telling me. It was said in less of a "Oh, it's okay, I'll provide you with information" way and in more of a "You will be obedient to *me"* sort of way. The psychologist dumped me into the deep end of ERP, moving from learning my triggers to rummaging around in a trash can in the same session. And though she told me that it could take my body more than two hours for the fight-or-flight response to die down, she wanted me out of her office as soon as my appointment time was up. She seemed to like dropping me down into that void and then kicking me out. Another thing that she liked to do was to prove to me that my thoughts and feelings were stupid and that I was just being an emotional brat. The kicker came about five months into the process. During a time of great stress (university finals) she just left me. I had been having a hard time, but making some progress. That day, I had finals to complete and errands to run. I asked her if we could skip the ERP for that day and she just told me that she couldn't help me and that I would *never* recover from OCD without spending a few months in an intense residential program and taking MAOIs and anti-psychotics. And then she just left me with a "Hope you have a good day!" and nothing else. No referrals, no talk of continuing care or *anything.* Now, that wasn't the end of my downward spiral (I'm doing much better today), but it was enough of a bad experience that it put me off of both types of therapy. Anyone have a similar situation or can think of another way to get around the OCD and live a more normal life?

I actually got the name of that psychologist from the International OCD foundation. D: It's been a few years now. I wonder if it would be worth sending something about my experience to them. I'm glad that residential treatment helped you, though! I've actually been doing a lot better as of lately. I ended up in a regular hospital a year ago last June and got put on Anafranil. So far it works pretty well, but man is it expensive out of pocket!

Yeah, she was... something. At the time I didn't realize what was going on, but looking back I'm like, "How did I not see it sooner?" I'll take a look into Dr. Hershfield. Thank you for the reccomendation!

I'm a hand washer. When I was having my worst symptoms, my hands would open up dozens of these little paper cut like fissures that hurt like hell. It was like having burns all over my hands. I swear by [O'Keefe's Working Hands](http://www.okeeffescompany.com/). It's not oily and absorbs really well. It doesn't cause any stinging and it works within hours to days. You can apply it whenever you need to. I prefer the body lotion formula (seems to absorb more quickly), but the original hand cream is great. Their lip balm is also amazing.

It's a control issue for me. I used to have really bad emetophobia because I've only been sick in that regard like three times in my life. So, if/when it does happen, it's *really weird.* I also have issues with the opposite end. The emetophobia is actually easier to explain than a fear of the runs. It's combined with IBS and frequent indigestion. It makes eating... interesting, to say the least. Some days, all I can do is laugh at myself.
This was in Georgia. I have a good therapist now, even though she doesn't do ERP (I have further issues, of course!).

I sometimes feel panicked from things that remind me of when I was a lot worse off. Going through what you've gone through is traumatic, though! Don't underplay that. Different experiences affect people in different ways and I think trauma is a perfectly fine way of describing it.

I feel you. Being so afraid by bodily sensations and actions can be absolutely suffocating. And since the gut is so influenced by stress, it goes into a feedback loop of not feeling well leading to panicking leading to not feel well. If it makes you feel any better, I'm not having that great of a night myself in regards to being afraid of being ill. It's the worst it's been in quite a few months. If you haven't already tried it, the distress tolerance aspect in Dialectical Behavior Therapy (DBT) can really help when you're heading towards a crisis area. It's not the gold standard for OCD because it doesn't directly address the obsessions and compulsions, but it can help when you don't have the spoons to battle it head-on. [Here's a link to a resource for some of the skills.](https://www.sunrisertc.com/distress-tolerance-skills/) They're useful to get you through the moment without hurting yourself or doing impulsive things you may regret once you calm back down.

WRITING.TITLE: What's your "Nuclear Potato"?
WRITING.TEXT: What's what you say to yourself when your OCD goes off the deep end and brings up a completely ridiculous theory? Something that is so laughably irrational that it doesn't bother you? Just something that is so out there that even *you* can't take it seriously. Mine is a "nuclear potato." One day, I was making a baked potato and while I was waiting for it to cook I found an news article about how a machine that is used for radiation therapy for cancer was stolen in Mexico and there was a risk of exposure for the people who stole it. My brain decided that it was going to mash this new factoid into my contamination obsessions. It started telling me a theory that somehow radiation from that one specific machine has contaminated my potato and that if I eat the potato I would become ill. Never mind that I: A) Live in Florida, nowhere *near* Mexico. B) The potato was grown in Idaho, again, *nowhere near Mexico.* C) The news story was from that day, *after I had bought the potato at the supermarket the day before*. I started laughing so hard from just how illogical the scenario was that my mom thought that something horrible had happened to me and that I was sobbing. The only thing I could get out was to tell her "Nuclear potato!" Has your OCD ever spat something like that out at you? Something that is so far out of left field that even *you* can be assured that the event couldn't take place?
Yes. This is how most treatment is set up. :)

Ah, okay, I see where you're coming from. Like you kind of want to be like "You know what? I'm going to do this dangerous thing to show myself what *real* fear and anxiety and torment is!" I feel like the throwing self in danger could be a form of self harm and I think it could be a manifestation of self-hatred or self loathing. So tread carefully. But doing things that are a *tiny bit* dangerous to give my body something to react to does make me feel somewhat more in control and calmer for some weird reason. Sometimes it comes in the form of exercising. Sometimes it's me dancing my heart out to a song in front of people. It doesn't have to be *dangerous*, it just has to be out of the normal. I went to art school where formal critique of your projects and ideas is a common thing. Before my final project, I'd get pretty nervous and excited to see what everyone would think of it. My heart would pound and I'd get jittery in a good way. And once it was over and went well, I'd feel *so* much calmer afterwards. I think there could be safe ways to do this. Lots of people like to seek out the adrenaline rush. It shouldn't be a part of the whole OCD thing. Like, using adrenaline inducing activities as an obsession and/or compulsion. Another thing that gets me that rush in a good way is performing on stage. Before I'd go on I'd be bouncing around backstage because of being excited and anxious. So, yeah, I think that maybe embracing good anxiety and excitement may work to help cope with "bad" anxiety. It'd get you used to being in that heightened state without freaking you out. I am not a professional, so I'd take my own post with a grain of salt.

Yes, this can happen and yes, it can be used as a gateway. The way I talk to myself is that I use it for proof that the ritual isn't needed. For me, I find that if I can stop a major ritual once, I have an easier time stopping it again. The more you can say no to it, the easier it gets. I hope you can use this to build up a recovery!

Pfft. Yeah, I can relate to that. "Do I actually need reassurance/attention or is it the OCD?" Too much one way and it fuels OCD, too much the other way and you just walk around assuming everyone hates your guts because you don't form normal bonds because you don't want to be weak with your OCD.
My parents call me Sheldon sometimes when I'm being particularly weird. But that one episode where Penny comes back from her family and she mentions that her nephew was sick? ***ME.***

That was kind of a dick move on the psychologist's part. You can't just dump that on someone and keep moving on. I have periods of derealization, dissociation, and depersonalization where I don't feel attached to myself. I've been having these symptoms since I was a toddler. 24 years later and nothing has progressed into more psychotic features. It's not to where I'm not in control, it just makes me feel weird. Sissociation and the like are very common features with anyone who has been through trauma, especially as a child. In and of themselves, they're not psychosis. You don't sound like you have delusions at all and have a firm grip on reality. Professionals can make mistakes or misdiagnose someone, especially after one appointment. One appointment is nowhere *near* the amount of time it takes to get a full assessment of someone's history and also understand what they're going through today. For example, I was misdiagnosed with Bipolar Disorder for being a little bit too chipper during a morning meeting while also saying that I have been having depressive and anxious symptoms. Before you try to change everything about your life, get a second opinion.

I don't have quite as many symptoms or rituals as you do, but yes, we can relate. It sounds frustrating and exhausting trying to live the way you describe. I do hope that with the help you'll be able to get some relief from the symptoms.

I think anyone in your shoes would be stressed! There may be some resources for new parents through the hospital or clinic you gave birth at. You are not alone in this; *many* new parents struggle with anxiety, stress, and depression. Now, you're saying that you don't actually want to kill yourself, right? What I've learned is that "I want to kill myself" or other thoughts of suicide can sometimes be shorthand in our minds for "I want the stress to stop right now." I've never been a parent, but I've had thoughts of suicide throughout my life. It helped immensely when I realized many of my thoughts of suicide weren't always literally my wanting to die. A lot of the times, I just wanted whatever bad thing that was happening to end. It was helpful for re-framing my thoughts.

WRITING.TITLE: How far does ERP go? (COCD people may want to stay away)
WRITING.TEXT: I'm going to be talking about #2 and issues related to it, so anyone who's really wary of that should stay away. #8203; I can't afford ERP, but I'm curious to know how far it goes and what it could look like for me. I have issues with going to the bathroom, particularly diarrhea. Six years ago I developed IBS out of the blue and it has dominated my OCD obsessions since then. I'm on a few different medications because of the IBS because the human body is cruel and gut and brain problems can synch up. I'm a lot better than I was at my worst (where I wasn't eating much of anything and was pretty damn sick), but there's a lot of room for improvement. How far does ERP go with these sorts of things? I've been incorporating new foods into my diet (some which I hadn't eaten in over five years). That's been going pretty well, actually, but it really doesn't address the obsession in any headlong way. I would think that it'd focus on expanding my diet more, learning how to listen to my body. But I don't know what the later stages would look like. Since I have problems with diarrhea, would I take laxatives to force my body to have a bowel movement just so I could expose myself to being sick? Just curious if anyone has had something like this.

You really don't deserve to be treated like this. I'm sorry you're in this situation because it is *not* normal. Since you're 20, they can't legally force you into treatment unless they have enough evidence to get you committed (going to hurt/kill self or others, etc.). Ultimately, you have the right to full control over your therapy and who you seek help from. I've had the same kind of struggles as you. College was really rough because not only did I need to do all of this schooling work, but I also had to fight the mental illness off. Both of these things are full-time jobs and it's exhausting to try to do both. Talk with your therapist and let her know what is going on. She's already shown to you that she can be trusted. She may give you a smaller fee (sliding scale pricing) or she may allow you to pay off your sessions a little at a time. I know that this is easier said than done when you're financially dependent on them. This could fall under financial abuse, especially if they've done this or something like this to you before.
It's a little bit of contamination based fears, yeah. I'm miles from where I used to be (I would not wish it on my worst enemy!), but I still want to get better.

No problem. We all need to rant now and then! I had some of the same issues with my parents when I was around your age. Some people have a really hard time dealing with the fact that they lose control over their kid as the kid gets older. I hope your parents come around. It's a lot easier when you have the support of family.

I tend to go too fast too soon if it's just me. I have a history of self harm when I'm pushed over the edge (I've probably given myself a few concussions over the years, but at least the scars are fading), so doing this without proper supervision may not be the right thing for me.

Yeah, when I had a lot of IBS symptoms early on I was less anxious about the process. The downside was that I was sick *all the time* for months. I've heard that distracting yourself and such is a no-no as far as an ERP therapy thing goes. I am glad you were able to get over your own symptoms, though. I had a fear of vomiting until I ended up in the hospital.

I used to do something like that and it's still really hard for me to not hurt myself when I'm at my breaking point. It's not a good thing, to say the least. For me it comes from a place where I have a hard time processesing intense emotion. If you're getting this on the regular, it may help to get a stress ball or something to take you energy out on. I find that once that little bit of energy is out things resolve themselves quickly. Those squishy things that are really popular with kids work great to take abuse out on. I figured that out after impulsively sweeping things off of tables. Thankfully nothing broke, but I had to then pick everything up off the ground, which took a bit. Suicidal thoughts suck because it makes everything seem so worthless. I'm glad that you were able to get away from that.

I wish that cannabis was legal where I live (Florida). I used to have a medical card for it, but once I started on the Anafranil in conjunction with the Paxil and Xanax I stopped using it. I mean, it isn't really "good" to be using substances to help you cope, but I found vaping CBD oil was as effective as a 0.5mg Xanax without the grogginess. It's also less addictive (I'm on daily Xanax and withdrawal is too much for me right now). The big thing is that the best treatment is to face your obsession, but sometimes that isn't practical.

Unfortunately, there are few options. You can try getting yourself committed at a hospital as a suicide risk. I've been through that and honestly, it wasn't the best environment for me. There was no one with OCD beside me and most of the people where I was were coming off of drug addiction or alcoholism. There were little DBT sessions during the day, but most people were too zonked out to do much. My experiences are really aligned with writer Norah Vincent in her book *Voluntary Madness: My Year Lost and Found in the Loony Bin.* The first hospital she gets admitted to is pretty much a standard mental hospital like the one I was in. It *will* be a complete and dramatic upheaval of your current life involving rituals because there are little in the ways of accommodation. For example, soap was given out by the attendants and was not available near the sinks in the bathrooms because someone could try to drink it to hurt themselves. Everything is done by a strict schedule and they basically tell you where you are supposed to be and what you are supposed to do at any given time. On one hand it kind of sucks to have all your freedom stripped away. But it was also kind of nice not having to think about what I was going to do. The good news is that they are totally prepared if you go off the deep end and have a breakdown. Tranquilizers are fairly common and your medication will be assessed and reworked. If you checked yourself in and were not admitted involuntarily, you usually have some control over what they give you. When I was there, I refused one of the medications they were trying to set me up on (Topamax, aka "Dopamax") because I had no history of bipolar disorder and the psychiatrist visited with me a total of five minutes. The entire experience didn't do anything for me except make me a little more paranoid around professionals. Resources seemed to be stretched thin. There *are* facilities for OCD specifically, but most of these other facilities are privately owned and will only take people who are insured. Some offer grants, but you'll need special paperwork and be able to jump through hoops. You try to get Medicaid in states that expanded the coverage. Even then, it depends on which company provides the coverage.

I have! My experience was that I was afraid that food was going to make me physically ill. It all stemmed from a time in 2013 where I was first diagnosed with IBS and a bunch of different foods started to make me sick (for example, anything really greasy, anything spiced, etc.). So I did what anyone would do: started tracking foods that made me feel ill. It just piled up from there until I had a twin disorder between an ED and OCD. If you can nip this problem in the bud now, you're going to be so much better off for it. Mine got to the point where I lost like 150lbs overall and I almost died after about 5 years with eating fewer and fewer things. It almost got to the point where if I wouldn't eat at the hospital, they were going to put me on a feeding tube. At my worst, I was eating a single bowl of Rice Chex cereal a day without milk. And that was it. I honestly don't know how I managed to keep going physically on that, but I was pretty damn heavy before and that was probably oddly a good thing.

Honestly, it sounds to me like you are getting better. It can be weird when your brain stops responding to the fears, though. It's like when I have a day without the general background anxiety of Generalized Anxiety Disorder. Keep heading the way you're heading. :)

*Absolutely.* From what I understand, it has origins in the "fight or flight" system. I've done *really* stupid shit when I get triggered into a "rage attack." I've broken things. If anyone is looking for a really good way to get that violent anger out, try either taking up ceramics and wedge the clay (basically beat the shit out of it until the air bubbles are gone) or make some bread and knead the bread dough. It is so therapeutic for me.

Sometimes professionals make mistakes, too. If you're looking at the symptoms and are noticing that you don't have them, then maybe it's time to seek a second opinion. The pros are not infallible. For example, I was once diagnosed with both Dependent Personality Disorder (DPD) and Avoidant Personality Disorder (APD) because I ticked off enough boxes in that general area of a standardized test. I looked at the criteria and I don't meet it. I don't have issues making decisions, am not afraid to express disagreement, and I don't need someone to do all of the caring for me in my life. I was pegged with DPD because I have issues with abandonment. In the same way, I was diagnosed with APD because of my low self esteem, but I don't have any of the anxiety issues around talking to people. You know yourself best. I'd get in touch with your current professional with your concerns about a wrong diagnosis and tell them that you'd like more of the explanation about why you were pegged with OCD.

A lot of that is valid roommate complaints. Just because she's comfortable living with the mess doesn't mean other people are. Your OCD is making it seem a lot more extreme, but yeah, the vast majority of people get disgusted by crusty dishes in the sink, ants in the food, and expired food. She's the problem here, not you. She needs to clean her shit up!

OCD + ED is a *terrible* combination. That's the one that got me so bad I had to go to the hospital because of malnutrition. I don't mind the attention span of a goldfish because there are times where I just completely forget what I'm obsessing about. I'll take any relief, even if it's weird! I'm sorry about the psychosis, though. That sounds unbearable. Hallucinations are the last thing you need in general and especially with someone who has checking issues.
No problem! I get the same way sometimes.

That sounds like a massive, exhausting clusterfuck and honestly you had every right to have had a freakout. I think it'd be perfectly reasonable to take a *long* break from them once they've moved. they have no have no right to do this to you. The good people over at Raised By Narcissists ([https://www.reddit.com/r/raisedbynarcissists/](https://www.reddit.com/r/raisedbynarcissists/)) would probably be able to point you in the right direction of how to deal with this stuff and how to go about setting boundaries so that this doesn't happen to you again.

I've run into the same issue and it's just how everything is laid out. It's possible to make it quite far into the Savage Divide while skirting around higher level enemy groups, though. I'm level 18 and just finished getting the key fragment from Blackwater Mine. It took a while and some luck, but I faced the mine with almost all level 8-22 enemies. But I'm way far off course for someone under level 20 and am going to go back to the earlier areas to level up.

I want to give you the biggest hug right now. You are totally not alone in this. IBS-D has turned my life upside down, too. There are a lot of days where I don't want to get out of bed because it means that a new days is starting and that I have to eat *something* for breakfast. I wish I had more advice for you and could tell you that it all gets better and all you have to do is xyz. But I'm down in the same pit. For me, the anxiety is worse and has led me into an eating disorder. IBS is most likely a cluster of different syndromes or disorders that we don't know about. Just know that there *are* new medications that are being worked on. Hopefully one of them works well.

Unfortunately. I also get back pains. For me, I've found that whatever gas there is triggers nerves and muscle pains for me. Like, my skeletal muscles cramp up and won't loosen up for a long time. It's bad enough that I've been prescribed a muscle relaxer (Flexeril). If I start to cramp up really bad, I take the muscle relaxer and it stops the pain in its tracks. It is *wonderful.* If you have the same kind of muscle symptoms, it may be worth looking at adding a relaxer in. They may make you really sleepy, though, so it's best used if you're at home. The other thing I've found that helps the muscle cramps is Lidocaine. It's available OTC. I massage some into all of the areas that cramp up and it takes the horrible pain away. It doesn't work as fully as Flexeril, but it's a safer thing to use.

WRITING.TITLE: Over six years, IBS has taken over my life
WRITING.TEXT: First and foremost: I *do* have doctors, a therapist, and a psychiatrist. I am getting all of the help that one can get. How do I even start this? Honestly, all of these points could be their own post, but I don't really want to go through it all in detail. I developed IBS one random day in May 2013. Just one day I was fine and the next day I was sick. And it just never got better. Went to doctors, had tests done, no one knows why all of a sudden my body decided to do this. I would get these episodes after dinner every night where my body decided to eject everything that I had put in it. It really hurt near the end as I would be passing yellow bile. It was bad enough that I'd just sit there and cry and sometimes scream with pain and frustration. I began to loathe food. It led me doing a low FODMAP diet on my own to try and figure out the "cause" of my illness. This spiraled into an eating disorder where I lost about 150 lbs and at one point I was living on a small bowl of Rice Chex a day. I was going to college and was busy and I used Imodium to control my symptoms. Anything to keep me off the toilet. Around the same time as the IBS began to develop, I developed severe OCD on top of all of the other mental diagnoses. To put it frankly: I am unstable and a control freak thanks to a difficult childhood full of bad things that I couldn't control. My OCD tangled up with the IBS and soon I was doing things like washing my hands 100 times before I could eat. That took a long time, but it wasn't particularly dangerous. But a few years ago, the OCD latched on to the Imodium and soon I was taking absurd amounts of the stuff. I ended up in the hospital twice because of it and I still went back to it because it has been the only thing that has helped me. I also take Bentyl, but I don't really know if it's working or not. During the hospital visits, I discovered that I could indeed eat some foods and have now a really limited, but looser diet of Bananas, bread, coffee, animal crackers, chicken, rice, raspberries, and grapes. So my eating has improved, but I'm still on the Imodium. I also had a bunch of tests done in the hospital and didn't have any signs of any kind of a disorder like IBD, Chrons, or Celiac. One of my triggers for OCD is having a symptom flare, so I will do *anything* to not have one. So not only are the flare ups are psychically painful, but they turn me into a psychological mess. I am just wondering if anyone here has had *any* kind of experience like mine. I'm going through therapy to help deal with it, but I've never met anyone who had my problems. Also, what is the best thing to put on your anus to make it stop burning if/when you pass bile? For me it's just pure agony.
Thank you for the cream suggestion. I have a GP appointment tomorrow and am going to ask for another referral. Thank you for taking the time to read my post and comment.

I wasn't handcuffed, but I was strapped down to a stretcher just for "safety reasons." My feet, knees, hips, chest, shoulders, and head. I hadn't shown any kind of resistance, but I can see why. The strip search caught me off guard. It was like, "Welp, okay, this is happening." Thankfully, I wasn't in crisis, so I had enough wits about me to just go with everything. It would've been hellish if I was actually unstable. I got in there because I went to the ER for a bad leg infection and they asked me if I had *ever* had thoughts of killing myself. Offhandedly. And because the question was phrased like, "Hey hon, have you ever had any thoughts of hurting yourself?" So instead of getting my leg treated, I was sent to psych. When I ended up back in the ER the next day because of my leg infection, I was told that the reason I was held was because I was violent at home and threatened to kill my cat with a knife. *I didn't even* ***have*** *a cat at the time.*

WRITING.TITLE: Consequences of never thinking you'll live long...
WRITING.TEXT: I never have been careful about taking good care of my teeth because I figured that if I was going to be dead by 25 it really doesn't matter. Now, at 26, I have to get a bunch of work done to my teeth to the tune of over $7k because I didn't take care of them. It was like "Aw, shit. I actually have to *care* about all this healthy living bullshit now?" A good chunk of me is still going, "Well, since I'm not going to make it to 30..." I'm sure someone else on here has had the same experience. I'm not looking for advice or anything like that, just some commiseration and dark humor.

My emetophobia was one of the solidifying reasons as to why I did *not* want to have kids. It would just be irresponsible of me. That being said, I'm sorry you're going through all of the anxiety. This time of the year is the worst for it. My emetophobia has been super mild these last few years, but I had a bit of a relapse when the national news decided to report on a norovirus outbreak the other week. Ugh. I don't know what those people are thinking, either. The best outcome is going on "autopilot," which I suspect is a way to describe dissociation and derealization. -- basically when your mind checks out and you just kinda putter around feeling like either you are not real or that your surroundings aren't real.
Honestly, I'd rather not even deal with having an inner child. It's one of the things I dislike the most during therapy.
Oooh! I like your style!

I could rant forever about psych wards and how traumatizing everything is! I'm sorry that you had to go through all of that. You'd think that a psychiatrist would know about panic attacks. That "excuse" she gave you is bull, either way.
*WOW.* That is... Wow...
They may use voice to text? Or maybe speak all emojis or prerecorded messages. I'm just making wild guesses.

I've already warned my parents that once I'm settled down longterm outside of their house, I'm going to be getting some danger noodles. I'm probably going to start off with a ball python because they're slow enough for me to catch. But eventually I'd like to have some garter snakes. The Calafornia Red Sided garters are just stunning and I love that they can be cohabitated and that they're fairly active. How is your Boa Constrictor? I think that'd probably the biggest snake I'd feel comfortable caring for.
*Wow.* That is *truly* classless.

Please *do* spoil that child! What a sick situation. That kind of thing can really screw kids up because they get the message that they are worthless. Although "neglect" is used mostly in the sene of having food, clothing, and a roof over their heads, kids can also be emotionally neglected and it sounds like he is.

I never thought about fostering! I'm sure there are a lot of snakes that need someplace to stay for a little while. I'd go for garter snakes first, but they're so fast and I need some experience catching slower noodles first. I'm glad that your boa is doing so well. I've seen a lot of videos about them and how they generally have excellent personalities.

I just want to give everyone who posted here a huge hug. Just remember that whatever you did you *never* deserved to be treated in that way by a mental health care worker. You *are* worthy enough to be listened to, comforted, and helped.
I'd love some stories as well, if you want to tell them.

I'm sorry you had such a hard time with birth control. Everyone acts like it's no big deal because the majority of people on it has manageable or no side effects, but it is a medication and not every persons' body works the same. It's great that you figured it out and were able to get snipped young. Now you have a brand new lease on life!

I tend to be a very caring person, but if someone I loved was in the *ICU* and some toddler or small bopped into the room or was causing mayhem, I would throw what could be called a shit fit. Seriously, if you're in the ICU you're not having a good time to begin with. Everyone is likely to be stressed and at the ends of their ropes. Life support equipment is everywhere. It's downright scary in there for most people. Toddlers should not be visiting people in the ICU. If they are somehow there, then the person who brought them needs to be on top of the kid at *all* times. Children are little disease vectors and chaos making machines, which are *horrible* things to have in the unit of the hospital that sees the most severe and ill people.

After I realized that little kids get away with what I could only dream of, I stopped being annoyed and started feeling envious. I wanted to sit on the floor and cry and carry when I had a bad day and they were all out of my favorite cereal at the grocery store. But did I? Nooooo. Because that's how you get sent back to a psych ward!
Huh, I don't remember writing this. In all seriousness, I feel. It was a miracle that I graduated from college. Even then it took me seven years. I'm on disability now.
I took pre-cal and I can't even remember what we hoping to accomplish with it. All I remember is so many fucking triangles.
Those poor kids! Could you report them to DCF? What they're doing is child abuse. Those parents should *not* have children.

I can imagine how infuriating it must be. That'd be like someone handing one of my photo prints to their kid to just destroy. I'd be aghast because I had put so much work into it and used only the highest quality papers and inks.
750,000 images. Holy shit. What a disgusting person.
I do! It's just instant schadenfreude. The dopamine rush you can get from remembering that you don't have to deal with *any* of their problems is just fantastic.

WRITING.TITLE: Anyone else like "I'd kill myself, but I really want to see/hear/watch/play XYZ."?
WRITING.TEXT: It's like right now I would really like to jump into a hole and disappear forever, but I really want to play the new Animal Crossing game coming out next month. What are y'all holding on for?
I got one of those from Matthew today. I guess I could've slipped up and not put the code in, but that would've *really* out of character for me.

"You're never going to get better." "I know what's best for you." "You're being useless." "Don't talk to anyone else about this." I'm actually pissed at myself for not documenting anything because I didn't realize at the time how abusive that patient-therapist relationship was. She blamed me for all of my problems and had no interest in helping me learn how to cope with my OCD and anxiety. She was constantly disappointed in me and I knew that she loathed our sessions. She let me go on for *six months* with her before she suddenly told me I was noncompliant and that she couldn't do anything more for me and that I was to vacate the premises immediately. And because I had gone through abuse and had no self-esteem, I let her do it to me. I was a fucking doormat.

If it makes you feel any better, I'm 27 and haven't even been on a date. And I'm a woman. *And* I'm Bi. All I can do is laugh about it because I'm so useless in the love department. I think there are more people like us out there than we realize. It's just one of those things where it's never really fully admitted because everyone's underlying question is "Well, what the hell is *wrong* with you?" It does sting to see so many people my age who are either in very serious relationships or married. It's expected of us that we start dating in middle or high school and continue to do so until we find "the one." Other routes are seldom heard about. I placate myself with the idea that there are what? Seven billion people in the world? There has to be at least one person out there that's willing to put up with me and my specific brand of bullshit. Normally, I'd try to say something to the effect of "we need to get out there and mingle," but it's a *terrible* time to be trying to date right now with the pandemic and everything. All we can do is really sit tight and wait it out. Easier said than done, I know. But there are a lot of people right now who aren't getting laid and everyone is going to be desperate once this is all over. Sorry for cracking so many jokes. I swear I'm trying to make you feel better.

You know what? I completely understand why you're so distraught. This is a lot for one person to handle. If you haven't already, it may be worth it to talk to your school's disability department. There may be a certain procedure for helping a student who has a certain set of circumstances come up. I've had classmates who've been able to finish their work after the deadline due to losing a grandparent and I was allowed to do so because of mental health issues. The worst they can say is "Sorry, I can't help you." Losing a dog is one of the worst things that has ever happened in my life. It is a very particular hell and there are a lot of people who don't understand it. To not be able to get that closure and final goodbye is heartbreaking and I'm sorry that it's happening to you. Could there be any way for you to give your parents an article of clothing or something that smells of you to maybe put around your dog? The coronavirus dies on soft surfaces in 2-3 days, but scent lasts a lot longer. Would perhaps bathing your dog be an option? The virus is both killed by soap and the soap physically removes the virus from hair and skin. There are also wipes for animals designed to kill germs. Your boss is being an asshole. I don't have a lot of work experience, so I can't give much advice other than maybe take it up with HR. But what he did to you isn't right. I have fewer ideas about the housing issue, though. I know that here in the US there are certain restrictions on landlords because of the pandemic. In a lot of places evictions aren't being done at all. I hope I could be of some help. I really do wish you the best.

Honestly? My parents. I'm an only child and it would just destroy them. The other thing is that I'm a registered organ donor. I just want to be useful in my death, you know? I'm not going to be doing anything with my body once I'm dead, so why not take it? I self harm, so that question is null for me. A word of warning: slamming your head into hard things is a really good way to give yourself a concussion and neck pain, but nothing more. Do not recommend it. ETA: I've tried my best to keep other people at arm's length. If I feel like I am becoming too close to other people, I pretty much just ghost them. I have a lot of acquaintances and know how to make people feel like they're close to me without actually being close. Like, a lot of people know intimate details about me and my struggles, but I don't really talk to anyone on the regular. The people I do talk to really only online or in text. It's not that I'm scared of rejection. I've been rejected plenty of times. But it almost feels like I'm trying to protect other people *from* me.
That question depends on whether or not I was the one to make the choice to fall.

Just remember, you asked. ;) I've had varying degrees of therapy throughout my life. The vast majority of it wasn't helpful, but when you're the "troubled child" no one seems to care. I had one therapist in college who was an absolute bitch. So, I was seeking treatment for OCD, but I also have other mental health issues. This was back in the days before I knew that C-PTSD even existed so I had zero idea why I had the issues that I did and felt the way I felt. My first mistake was simply having gone through therapy before. She was just really rude and somewhat aggressive when she found out that I already knew about exposure therapy and all of that jazz. She always acted like she was doing me some kind of favor just by seeing me. She actually made me cry in my very first session with her. She told me that my dissociation and derealization were my choices and that I was the one at fault for having them. I didn't know that they were responses to stress. I just thought I was losing it and she seemed to agree with that. I once asked her if she had any good recommendations as far as books that may help me. She had an entire wall of her office completely filled with psychology books. There had to be hundreds of them. And she just snapped at me and said, "No. You *only* listen to what *I* tell you." The therapist was also very invested in getting me to a psychiatrist and on a completely different course of various drugs. I was already taking Paxil and Xanax at that point and I didn't want to abruptly change medications because I was living alone and I was in the middle of a full semester of school. She started telling me things like I'd never recover from OCD and that the *only* way that I could even possibly get better is if I was in an inpatient facility and it'd take months of work and a lot of drugs to help me. Still, she was the esteemed professional in the area, so I figured that my problems were my fault and she was just giving me tough love or something. I was supposed to be doing exposure therapy, which is something that has to be done in the right way or else it's just traumatic rather than therapeutic. I had to go through her trash bin and handle everything that was in there and then I wasn't allowed to wash my hands afterward. And there was some nasty stuff in there like old food and other things like that. I also had to touch my face and mouth with dirty, nasty hands. Eventually, she decided to give me a big test of all different kinds of disorders. It was like a bubble in test with hundreds of questions. It took an hour just to complete. The results came in two sessions later. I had, in no particular order: Generalized Anxiety Disorder, Major Depressive Disorder, Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder, Avoidant Personality disorder with Borderline features, and Dependent Personality Disorder with Borderline Features. With little chance of getting better. There was one session in which she wanted me to do an exposure, but I was in the middle of finals and had a *ton* of work and other chores that needed to be done and that I didn't have the sanity to spare. Basically, if I had done the exposures, it would've screwed with my entire life. I wouldn't be able to get projects done, I wouldn't be able to get groceries, I just didn't have the spoons to spare. Then, about two weeks later, she told me that we weren't making any progress, I was noncompliant with her treatment, she couldn't help me, and that this was the last time I would be allowed in her office. Sort of like "Can't help you, have a nice life!" No sort of follow-up care, no suggestions as to who could possibly help me, just a stern warning to scram. Oh, man, was *that* fun! Let's keep in perspective that I was a model patient. I only spoke to her during sessions, I did all of my homework, I never *ever* bothered her outside of the hour I had to spend with her a week, I was polite, I was always on time, I was agreeable and friendly, I was trying my *damndest* to please her. I tried *desperately* to please her. I ended up seeing this lady for *six months* before I had a breakdown and had to leave college for a while. So yeah, that was the story of how I was mistreated by a psychologist and didn't realize that I wasn't the one at fault until *years* later.

*Yes!* The only real noise I make when I cry is shaky breathing. It sounds like I'm gasping for breath. But I can control even that if I need to. I *can* cry with noise, but only when it's "appropriate." If I feel like I am overreacting or crying about something stupid, I don't make noise. E.g. Dog died = loud crying, sad scene in movie = silent crying.

I feel this. Like, anything that's *supposed to* be traumatizing doesn't traumatize me. I just bounce right back from it. Like almost dying? Bounced back from it, no issues. My sink got clogged? Cue me absolutely losing my mind over it.

I'm on disability, mainly to be able to get health insurance. It's one of those things where I'd either have to work three part-time jobs just to pay an insurance premium or be perpetually pregnant to get Medicaid in this Godforsaken state. It means I have to live with my parents because I can't afford any sort of housing. It's... fine. The abuse has (mostly) stopped as I got older. The only thing that drives me up a wall is that I'm still treated like a teenager and am given little agency even though I'm 27. I *was* thinking about going back to college and getting my Master's, but that has been put on hold because of COVID-19. This January was the first time in like five years where I had a direction and plan to become independent, but *nope*, can't have that apparently.

I think it's fairly normal for dissociation. It used to freak me the fuck out when I was younger because I didn't have a word for what I was experiencing. When I first heard about dissociation and derealization I was absolutely stunned that the sensations had a name and that it wasn't just me who was experiencing them! I lose contact with my body. All sensation, especially touch, is dulled to the point where I have to be careful about what I'm doing because pain won't kick in as it should. I've hurt myself a few times because I just didn't have that sense to tell me that something was wrong.

I've found that I really can't live with housemates. I could never let my guard down until I was alone and it'd make me very prone to burnout because I could never relax. I hear you about the "new normal." I was sincerely hoping that things would be different, but... The world still seems the same as it always was, but now with people who are more crabby than they were before.

WRITING.TITLE: Confusion Regarding Loving Parents
WRITING.TEXT: I'm fairly new to all of this. I'm sure that this question has been asked dozens of times, but I tried my best to find another post like this and came up with little. Does anyone else find that they're completely split when it comes to their parents? My experience has been two totally different lives. My parents are either wonderful and supportive or terrible and angry. It is either one or the other and when things change they change very quickly. It's enough to give me whiplash. I know that nothing they do is *intentional*, but that's of little comfort sometimes. It's normally peaceful and quiet and everything is fine. But then I get into huge fights with my dad where he becomes verbally, emotionally, and sometimes physically abusive. He yells, screams, threatens me, and occasionally either hits me or knocks me down. He always feels terrible about how he acts and always apologizes to me after he's cooled down, but he doesn't do anything to stop from doing it again the next time. The rest of the time he's great. He's loving and caring and would do anything for me. We get along well. My mom is the quiet one. When my dad and I fight, she hides. She's done this since I was a little kid, leaving me to face my father pretty much alone. She reappears to assess the damage and to comfort me, but it's too little too late at that point. There is generally a period of weeks to months between fights where everything is normal. I'm always on the alert to react and avoid my dad if he's in a bad mood so that we don't clash. I've always been "the mentally ill one" in the household. My parents don't think that I can survive without them, so they've effectively kept me in an adolescent phase of life even though I lived alone when I was in college. I'm 27, going on 28, and have little autonomy in my life. Has anyone else been just left completely confused by the doublethink? I *know* that the way that they treated me and are treating me is wrong. But at the same time, I feel like I can't live without them and have a hard time staying mad at them. Is this the whole "fawn" reaction? It just feels like I have two sets of parents.

I'm in the *exact* boat. It's absolutely bizarre going from "I need these people out of my life to heal" to "I need these people to help me survive" within the same ten minutes. The abuse has stopped, only reprised somewhat when my dad and I clash. I'm a lot better at controlling my responses to him now that I'm an adult and can defuse the situation by physically stepping back. At least we both found this place. It helps to talk to other people.

Tension in the room is a good way to boost me into fight/flight/freeze mode, even if it doesn't have anything to do with me. I'm sorry you're in the same situation. It does make me feel better that it's not just me, you know? I think a good part of the loneliness that C-PTSD brings is the feeling that you're the only person who feels the way you do.

It was always a great time as a kid. I *eventually* caught on and learned to read the atmosphere in the room, but man, it was just bizarre for my child self to suddenly have people suddenly be very angry at me. I didn't realize how uptight I am until I lived on my own. Knowing I had my own space where I could do anything I pleased at any hour of the day was a relief. I'm currently working on getting back to that spot.
I hate that there are so many of us in the same situation! I'm dependent on my parents financially, too.
I feel you. My problem is that they've convinced me that I can't survive without them running things. Logically, I know all of the steps to independent living. In practice, I freeze up.
Thank you for reaffirming this for me. It's so strange to know how to spot abuse in other people's situations, but being unable to see it as clearly when it's happening to me!

You're good. I feel the same way about my parents. At this point in the game, guilt isn't really going to help anything. I just wish that they'd realize that they've got issues that they need to work out.
I'm sorry that you've had to go through this, too. You don't deserve any of it.

I feel that! My last psych just randomly decided to close shop one day without warning. I felt so bad for the nurse he had working for him because she was stuck cleaning up the mess and attempting to contact all of his patients. Be pissed off. That is legitimately bullshit because just randomly dropping a psych med dose will fuck you up big time. She should have let you know if she was changing your medication and you should have had a say in it! I really hope you're able to locate someone who doesn't suck at their job. Just remember that they're working for *you* and not the other way around.

To be quite honest, I have no idea. I kind of heave myself out of bed every morning with a hearty "FUCK!" It may be better to not compare yourself to others. You're dealing with a lot more than most people and shouldn't judge yourself. I think that for a lot of us, it'd be comparable to running a marathon with 100lbs strapped to your back. Sure, there are people who are faster, but very few of them are carrying that weight around. The people without the weight are at an advantage. I hope this makes some sort of sense.

You're definitely not alone in this feeling. It's frustrating to just barely be able to make ends meet and then watch as the people who have more than enough get *more.* It may not be productive to dwell on the situation with your roommate, but there's nothing wrong with allowing yourself to feel what you're feeling. I know that I struggle with guilt over feeling envy towards other people, but it's a natural emotion. It just depends on how you act on those emotions.

First, I hope that your tests come back normal. It sounds like you have a lot to deal with already and don't need that added on top of everything. I don't feel like your feelings are irrational. You went through something that no kid should have to go through and had to put up walls and barriers to cope. Having your body examined can be extremely uncomfortable and triggering for people who *haven't* been through CSA. I went through a lot of traumatic medical procedures as a kid and I can't stand having people touch my body in a clinical way. It makes me want to curl into a ball in the corner of the room and cry every time. I went looking for resources and I found two things that might help. This first link is a [PDF intended for doctors](https://www.wcsap.org/sites/default/files/uploads/webinars/sexual_assault_advocacy_healthcare_access_youth_2012_06/getting_through_medical_examinations_providers.pdf) describing what they can do to make a sexual assault survivor more comfortable during procedures. It's useful to know what steps can be taken and what kind of accommodations they can make. Since you're having issues with someone else touching your breasts, they can allow you to do much of the positioning yourself. It'll probably take longer, but you'll be in control. It would be best to contact the office or testing center beforehand to explain your situation. It's something that they should be used to doing and they should be immediately understanding about it. If they're not, you may want to find a different center. Here's [a post with tips for mammograms,](https://www.sparkpeople.com/mypage_public_journal_individual.asp?blog_id=5936794) written with survivors in mind. It repeats quite a bit of what's in the practitioner guide but adds a few other ideas in.

I either feel pain acutely or not at all. There are areas of my body that I can't feel pain around for some reason. Like, my hands are less sensitive to heat or pain because I had years where I'd wash my hands obsessively until they bled. My thighs aren't too sensitive to touch. And I have a constant back and neck ache and often don't realize it until I actually stop to think about it. My best guess is that it has something to do with dissociation.

Getting hit by a car = zero emotional response Toilet backed up = full on meltdown I can remember every little small thing that has happened to me, but the big "scary" events are forgotten at the first possible point.

I'm really good at compartmentalizing thoughts and pushing away useless thoughts when a crisis takes place. Like, so many people are freaking out about this virus, but it's like I've been preparing for this my entire life. I've already run all the worst-case scenarios and found solutions for them.

For me, I think it's ["Girl Anachronism"](https://youtu.be/VGrqcQWRVGE) or ["Runs In The Family"](https://youtu.be/SqW9DR09Me4) by Amanda Palmer. The English cover of ["Dramaturgy"](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=od8YbI9NJ2E) by Eve is another good one. ["Self Inflicted Achromatic"](https://youtu.be/6eh39VWPIj4) (TW for suicidal thoughts) works, too, especially with the depression.

WRITING.TITLE: DAE loathe the inner child?
WRITING.TEXT: TW: mentions of trauma, aggression, suicidal ideation, self-harm I'm still fairly new to all of this, but the big issue I'm running into is the whole inner child thing. There is an intense and feral hatred for my inner child or child self. Like, it takes me a good amount of self-restraint to tolerate the idea and not rush to metaphorically kill it. I just don't like kids to begin with. I feel almost zero affection towards them. I'm not mean to them or anything like that, but I definitely don't enjoy the time I spend around them. I'm *never* becoming a parent or any kind of parental figure. That's non-negotiable for me, to the point where I won't even consider any kind of romantic relationship with anyone who wants kids or who's on the fence about them. To be honest, I think my childhood ended by the time I was 10. I had already dealt with my father's outbursts, my grandparents dying, dieting and hating my body, physically having an adult body (precocious puberty), self-harm, suicidal ideation, threats of being institutionalized for the rest of my life, taking adult doses of psychiatric medication, abuse from a psychiatrist, being Queer while growing up Catholic, traumatic medical procedures... I've probably forgotten things. Either way, I find the whole inner child thing hard to process because I still blame myself for everything that happened to me. I don't remember a time when I *didn't* hate myself. My earliest memories are of me wandering around, being dissociated and derealized and confused because I felt like I was in a dream. I had to be 3 or so and didn't realize that the dreamlike feeling had a name. Anyone else in a similar boat? ETA: Now that I've really thought about things, quite a bit of it comes from being raised Catholic. From a young age, it was impressed upon me that I had to do the "right" things and be the "right" way. I was taught that evil in the world comes from sin and thus deduced that if bad things happened to me it was because I was sinful and deserved it. It was only further complicated by my realization that I am Bi. Suddenly *who I was* was in and of itself a problem. I was no longer just *committing* sins, but my own love *was* the sin.

I can tell you that you're not alone. I have the same problem. I will delay good and fun things in my life and deny myself things that I've looked forward to. It's connected to the whole punishment thing that I have with myself.
Toxic certainly *does* describe the feeling. I'll check out John Bradshaw's stuff. Thank you for the recommendation!

Going through old pictures and videos is always super weird for me. I saw myself one way at the time, but looking at it again as an adult makes me see that I *was* just a kid. I hope that you're able to see yourself with more compassion. It sounds like you're making good progress with your therapist. It's amazing that we've been put through such a wringer that having basic needs seems like too much.
For me, it's such a weird feeling because I don't harbor that sort of hatred for anyone or anything else. It's like a black pit.

I hope that you've been able to calm down and center yourself. You did a really brave thing by calling the residential treatment center and I'm sorry that it basically got thrown back in your face. It's always frustrating when you can't get someone to understand what you're going through.
It isn't quite the same for me. I don't have that loathing for any child except for myself as a child. It's less hatred of kids and more self loathing.

I eventually ended up dabbling in witchcraft because I figured that if I was already going to hell, I may as well do it thoroughly. I actually played this part while I was still a peer minister in high school. Which now is quite objectively funny.
That makes sense. Kids can be unimaginably cruel.

I've felt the same way in the past. If any authority figure (teacher, professor, boss, etc.) gets mad in my presence, I immediately start fawning and appeasing behaviors. Even if they aren't mad at *me.* Just mad in the same general area.

WRITING.TITLE: DAE? "You're always so serious!"
WRITING.TEXT: I'm pretty sure the answer is going to be "Yes" on this, but I want to ask anyway. Does anyone else get told that they're too serious or that they're "too intense" for people? I'm always ready to talk about all sorts of serious stuff (the news, politics, religion, science, etc.), but I find that I'm often dismissed. I seem to have a talent for making everything awkward, both online and offline. I can't even count how many threads that I've killed on various message boards, even when I'm *not* being serious. Now, I'm not being inappropriate. I'm not striking up casual conversation with a random person and immediately talking politics. I can read the room and I'm decent at small talk. I like making people laugh. I just don't get topic fatigue when discussing heavy matters. It's just frustrating because I'm always there for people when they need to talk about something serious going on in *their* lives or if they *do* want to delve into a deeper discussion. People come to me for advice. Can anyone else commiserate?

According to my parents, I was a brat. I remember them telling me this particular poem: There was a little girl, Who had a little curl, Right in the middle of her forehead. When she was good, She was very, very good But when she was bad she was *awful*. It's a misremembered version of [this poem](https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/44650/there-was-a-little-girl). I don't remember too much else. I know that I was dissassociating and derealizing starting from when I was 2 or 3. I kept asking my parents if I was in a dream because I felt floaty and unreal. I also had no idea how to act around other kids because I only interacted with them a few times a month. Otherwise, all my company was adults.

You were definitely abused by your mom. At the very least physically, emotionally, and verbally. What you've been through is not okay and you have a right to be upset about it. Don't doubt yourself on this. You're feeling this way for many reasons and they're pretty damn big, too. It sounds like you didn't get to have very much of a childhood at all. It's completely unfair that you were taught that there was something "messed up" about you. I know what that feels like and it sucks. Just because her spanking didn't leave any marks doesn't mean that it wasn't abuse. It's unacceptable to hit a child and physical discipline has had huge negative impacts on people. Your mom is also gaslighting you by asserting that "it wasn't that bad." She's questioning your reality and planting those seeds of doubt within you. This is a manipulation tactic. The venting about her sexual and romantic relationships to you when you were a kid was not good, either. That's emotional incest. She shouldn't have relied on you for emotional support that she should have gotten from another adult. And, needless to say, her fixation with your body was especially cruel. No one should have to go through all of that crap. We live in a culture that's obsessed with looks and for you to have gotten that harassment from your mom is just cruel. What your dad did to you in anger wasn't okay, either. He was the adult and shouldn't have taken his anger out on you or any member of your family. That being said, I *can* understand what he did. I have a hard time with anger, too, and I have done things that I've really regretted. The fact that he not only apologized sincerely every time it happened and has gotten help for his anger issues can't undo what he did, but it's the responsible and mature thing to do. He should have been there to support you and shield you from your mother. But that's just me making assumptions that he didn't. Either way, it sounds like you have at least a decent relationship with him. I don't have siblings, so I can't really speak on the issue of sibling abuse, but do know that it's something that does exist. I know that kids, especially boys, are often treated with a "kids will be kids" attitude, and that can contribute to people excusing sibling abuse as something that kids just do naturally. There's no one right way to feel about all of this. I know that I have all sorts of mixed feelings about my parents. But that is okay and normal. You're allowed to have feelings. If I were you, I'd keep limiting contact with your mom. She's shown you all your life that she really doesn't care. I'm so sorry that you've had to go through all of this, but you're among people who understand here. Things can get better.

I hear you loud and clear and have been through something similar with a group of friends. They have good intentions but don't think of the ramifications of their scenarios. Like having a revolution and fighting for what you believe in and all that jazz sounds kind of fun when you haven't been exposed to that kind of upheaval. It sounds heroic and like a movie come to life. My group of friends came to the conclusion that we're not moving fast enough with the way that society is progressing and that the best thing would be some kind of huge conflict. They didn't understand why I hesitated to call for the violent overthrow of the government even though I stood with them in their beliefs. War is not fun. It's not pretty. It's not glorious. It is tragic, profound loss. It is interrupted food and supply lines. It's having to decide which of your patients has a better chance of living because you don't have enough supplies to treat them all. It's being awoken to the sounds of gunfire and explosions and not knowing if you're going to be the next one hit. It's having to live not knowing if a random stranger is going to be desperate enough to kill you to get food. It's so many horrible things that I don't know of because I've never seen war up close and personal. I don't *want* to see it. It doesn't take a genius to figure out that war is not a fucking game. I think that what we're facing in the US is vitally important and it *is* worth fighting for. But that doesn't mean that I *want* to see massive conflict. If we can resolve this through legislation, then let's do that instead. In real life, conflict is less *Call of Duty* and more *This War of Mine*. We've already lost over 100,000 people in the US just to COVID-19. We don't need a war on top of it.

I stim a lot, but I know how to make it unnoticeable. I have a weird mish-mash of traits, so I may be somewhere on the spectrum. If I were to be born today, I would have been at least assessed for it. The most obvious one would probably be the happy/excited hand flapping and bouncing. I also get pretty physically bouncy when I'm excited. I sometimes [fingerspell](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fingerspelling) words I'm speaking when I'm thinking hard. I try my hardest to limit these movements when I'm around other people, but sometimes it sneaks out. I also have a tendency to display the "raptor hands" (explained better [here](https://overexplainingautistic.tumblr.com/post/168045062854/hi-what-are-raptor-hands-i-see-people-talk-about)) resting position when I stand. It's a very stereotypical posture for autistic people. I do this a lot when I'm at home, but I don't *think* I do it around other people. I toe walk sometimes, too, and fidget a lot. I've used [tangles](https://www.tanglecreations.com/) (a common stim toy) to the point of breaking. I bounce my leg when I'm bored or stressed. I *constantly* bite on my lip or cheek. So long answer short: Yes, I stim. That being said, stimming is normal for everyone regardless of neurotypicality. It's just that neurotypical stimming is seen as more normal. For example, leg bouncing, foot-tapping, pen clicking, and pencil twirling. All stim behaviors, but they're seen as normal.

First off, I'm so sorry to hear about your dog. People process grief in totally different ways. Feeling absolutely nothing is often totally *normal* with grief. It's one of those times where dissociation is a typical reaction and is seen in "normal" people. When one of my dogs died, I didn't feel anything at first. It was only after a few days to a week when it finally hit me. This is different from not allowing yourself to feel things. Just check in on yourself a few times a day to access and address what you may be feeling. A [feelings wheel](https://i0.wp.com/dontmindmeblog.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/12/emotion-wheel.jpg?fit=1332%2C1332 amp;ssl=1) may be helpful.

Games have always been a way of escape for me since I was a kid. I honestly couldn't imagine my life without them. Playing a role in video games has helped me both learn about other people and learn about myself. The characters in different games have been an *immense* comfort in my life. Like, right now, *Animal Crossing: New Horizons* really helps to soothe me while the world is just crazy. Nothing really terrible can happen to you or other characters in it, so I feel like I can fully relax and chill when I'm playing. I play *The Sims* in a similar way to unwind. *Harvest Moon* and *Stardew Valley* are also relaxing. And *Minecraft.* I'm also a big Pokemon fan. I got *Pokemon Yellow* for my birthday when I was 5 or 6. I was lured in by the anime originally but loved the games, too. I remember how hyped I was for *Gold* and *Silver.* I still play a lot of Nintendo games in general. On the opposite side of things, playing horror games allows me to purposefully invoke that fight/flight instinct and learn how to better think on my feet and let myself experience what it feels like to be afraid without having to worry about anything actually hurting me. I like psychological horror games better than ones that rely on jumpscares. In that regard, I really like *Layers of Fear* and *Observer. Doki Doki Literature Club* was really messed up in a good way. And *Yume Nikki* and *Ib.* I'd consider these games to be highly triggering and while I personally don't get triggered by them, other people definitely will be. I also really like RPGs, whether they're smaller scale or if they're open world. So I like both *Fallout 4* and *Undertale* a lot. All of them allow me to carve out a safe space to practice and run through different stories. I like games that let me customize the character a lot, but I'm happy to assume the form of a pre-made character. Hell, I even like walking simulators. Or anything that I can either experience or build a story with. The one genre that I really don't touch are MMOs. Games are an escape from other people for me and *having* to interact with other people in real time really dampers things. I have no problem being around other people, but I don't want to let other people down, so I don't play games that require teams. As far as how they have influenced my journey, I've used characters and stories to comfort myself in the absence of comforting people in my life. I've engaged in maladaptive daydreaming when things become too stressful. I'm working on building more meaningful relationships IRL.

WRITING.TITLE: Dental Trauma as a Child and Getting Treated
WRITING.TEXT: TW: Body horror, medical malpractice, medical procedures. ***This is pretty fucked up.*** My teeth are a mess and I have portions of my gums that are inflamed and have been bothering me since the beginning of the week. I'm probably going to have to see the dentist and get checked out. Problem: I have major unresolved trauma surrounding going to the dentist and really don't trust anyone putting things inside my mouth. I've told the story to a few therapists and they seem to be a little too stunned by the story to really be of much help. I really don't need any advice or anything. Just a recognition that what happened is fucked up. Anyway, when I was about 3, I went to the dentist. The dentist said that he had to pull out my four front teeth on my upper jaw. So all of my upper incisors. The dentist and his assistants kicked my parents out of the room to perform the procedure. I remember being put on a metal table and pinned down with two people on each limb. I screamed for my parents, but they were in the waiting room and couldn't hear me. No one attempted to soothe me at all. In fact, they were angry with me because I was kicking and pushing them away as best as I could. As any child would have done. They tried to put their fingers in my mouth and I started biting. That's when they shoved a metal gag into my mouth and strapped it tight around my face (something like [this](https://images-na.ssl-images-amazon.com/images/I/416vXncE2TL._AC_SX425_.jpg)). Then they forcefully pulled the teeth out without any numbing agent or pain medication. I don't remember how painful it was because I think my mind may have blacked it out, but I *know* that the teeth weren't loose or anything. I do remember that afterward I had these huge sores the size of half-dollars on the outside of my cheeks where the gag had worn on the skin. My parents were angry and were going to sue the pediatric dentist who did it to me, but we didn't have enough money to afford it. As far as I know, the place is still in practice. This would be reprised a few years later when the doctors needed to take my blood. It was the first time I had had it done and was terrified. But they just held me down in the same way and took it. It's a small miracle that I've been to *any* doctor since then.

Every single time I get my period I am taken aback at just how bad it can get. I actually have to have people remind me I'm on my period because I just get this black hole of paranoia, mood swings, and nihilism. You'd think I would be able to immediately identify it, but each month I'm like "Whoa, holy shit."

WRITING.TITLE: I never thought my breaking point would be because it's too fucking hot.
WRITING.TEXT: I'm normally hanging somewhere around the edge on a good day, but everything that's going on is coming to a head because the A/C at my house broke and this just might be the straw that breaks the camel's back. It is 88F with humidity in the house because we live in Florida, the dumbest state to ever exist. Seriously no one should live here because it *sucks.* The beaches are okay, but the rest of the state is just... no. So, have any of you just wanted to kill yourself for the stupidest reason ever? I'm pretty sure I'll be okay. This year has just really sucked so far, I didn't get any sleep last night, I'm on my period, the heat makes me feel ill, and there's no escape from it. Hopefully, we'll get this fixed sooner than later because the heat is seriously draining any will to live from my body.
This could work! Thank you! It should be getting better soon since the sun is going down. It's just one of those things where it got progressively more miserable as the day went on.

I feel you. I don't know what I'd actually do in that kind of situation. I'd like to think that I'd heroically sacrifice myself to save others, but I just don't know. I *do* know that if I made it out alive and other people died, I'd never forgive myself.

WRITING.TITLE: Giving up on the concept of love
WRITING.TEXT: I'm 27, Non-Binary, Bi, and am so "far behind" absolutely everyone that it's not even funny. I've never been in a relationship, never been kissed, never been even flirted with. For years I held on to this idea that someone would like me. But then I realized yesterday that being in a relationship would mean that I'd be forcing someone to put up with me and I wouldn't want to curse other people with my existence. Especially in such a personal way. I'm one of those people who technically has friends, but has never really come fully out of their shell. No one really knows me. And I try to keep them an arm's length away so that I don't hurt them, but at the same time it's as lonely as *fuck.* I don't really know where I'm going with this.
